name: Abbad
short description: Ptolemaic fort located on the Edfu-Berenike road, 22 km from Edfu.
description: Ptolemaic fort located on the Edfu-Berenike road, 22 km from Edfu.It has been fully excavated by the MAFDO in 2017-2018.Because of its position (first station for the caravans and expeditions to the Red Sea, when coming from Edfu), the fort of Abbad had a crucial role on the road: it is the place where the members of the caravans gathered, together with their animals, to form the caravan (Cr√©py, Redon forthcoming). It is also the place where the caravans and expeditions were supplied with water and bread. The fort was equipped with eight bread ovens, a well and two tanks, as well as three outside basins and a supplementary tank.Two buildings functioned with the fort, both equipped with several rooms (3 to 4) and an open-air courtyard; they probably acted as caravanserai, to settle the persons and animals that were temporary gathered at Abbad before their departure to the desert.The 2017-2018 excavations show that the fort was occupied from the end of the reign of Ptolemy II up to the late 3rd c. BC, and abandoned for some decades. Thereafter, it was reoccupied, in the early 2nd c. BC, by shepherds and travelers. A small Roman reoccupation (probably linked with the reopening of the well) occured in the 1st-3rd c. AD, and a most significant one during the 5th and 6th c. BC, when the well was again reopened. This accords well with what is known about the preference for the more northerly route between Koptos and Berenike during the Roman and Late Roman period but is a useful reminder that the route from Edfu was not entirely dormant. It is also striking that 2nd c. BC material was found, that shows that the forts of the Edfu-Berenike road were abandoned and that the Ptolemaic state did not invest in this road again after the Theban revolt, but that it was still in use, by merchands and travelers in the second part of the Ptolemaic era.During the MAFDO excavations, several sandstone blocks with New Kingdom inscriptions, pottery and beads were discovered either reused or under the Ptolemaic fort, and three cartouches of the king Tutankhamen are already mentioned by Lepsius and Green. It is therefore possible that a first settlement, dated to the New Kingdom (and possibly contemporaneous with the equipment of the nearby site of El-Kanais [SIT0094]), was built in Abbad, with a well and maybe a chapel.

name: Abiyad
short description: Large settlement of unknown function
description: Large settlement comprising dozens of buildings, mainly one-roomed but also more complex with 2 or 3 rooms. They are located on both sides of a small wadi, and are spread over more than 800 m N/S.In absence of any material, in particular no tools were seen by the Klemms during their survey, nor by S.E. Sidebotham or I. Bragantini and their team, it is difficult to assess the nature of the settlement or its date.According to Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 79, it could have been a pilgrim's settlement on the route to Safaga, and Sidebotham, Barnard, Pyke 2002 suggest that it could have been a Christian settlement of the Late Roman period, like Hitan Rayan, but it is impossible to verify this.In the vicinity there is a modern phosphat mine (Umm el-Huwaytat Mine) and a modern tomb, the tomb of Sheikh Awwad. The Gasus station is located 8km to the east. It is 10km from the Safaga station.

name: Abu Ashayir
short description: Large settlement, maybe from the New Kingdom
description: A large settlement maybe dated from the New Kingdom, but without certitude since no material has been found.The Klemms based their conclusions on the architecture of the huts.As there are no traces of gold exploitation in this area, it is difficult to know the purpose of this big settlement.

name: Abu Diyeiba
short description: Amethyst mining site in Ptolemaic and Early Roman times
description: The site of Abu Diyeiba was dedicated to the exploitation of amethyst. It is located about 25 km SW from Safaga. The Delaware team carefully surveyed the site in 2004 and this description is based on their final publication (Harrell et al. 2006).The site comprises a dozen huts, and hundreds of mining excavations. Several inscriptions (related to cultic activities) were found by Tregenza in 1951, by modern miners, and in 2004 by the Delaware survey. According to Harrell et al. 2006, p. 127, it is one of only two known quarries for this gemstone in Egypt. The amethyst quarry consists of between 400 and 500 trenches scattered across an area of nearly 3 km2, which is much greater than that of the el-Hudi amethyst mine (the other known one).Apart from the trenches, cairns, two settlements with less than a dozen huts, a small temple, isolated huts and two graves are recorded (the isolated huts and graves are not visible on the satellite images and are thus not in the subsites), but no well. The constructions are very few, compared to the large number of excavations, which suggests that the majority of the workers probably lived in tents and that the dead were sent back to the Valley. It probably also means that the occupation was seasonal.From the inscriptions and pottery, the occupation period is dated to the Ptolemaic (the inscriptions are from the 2nd c. AD) and Early Roman period.

name: Abu Garahish
short description: Ptolemaic worker village and possible small stop on the road from Edfu to Berenike
description: The main site of Abu Garahish is a Ptolemaic worker village located at the intersection of the wadi Muweilha and wadi Abu Garahish, 9.8 km east of the Ptolemaic fort of Bir Samut.It was partially excavated by the MAFDO in 2016, in parallel with their work at Bir Samut.The site consists of several clusters of buildings on the side and at the bottom of the hills located on the southern side of the wadi Muweilha. A large building (Building 1, maybe a dormitory) is located in the middle of the settlement. Other buildings (Building 4-5) and a round tomb (Roman?) adjoin it. On the top of a hill, a building (Building 2) dominates the valley. Below, halfway up behind this eminence, there is a flat work area and a small construction (Building 3). Huts and more complex buildings (Rooms 52-63) located in the northeast of the village are arranged in terraces, at mid-slope. They are distinguished by a fairly neat construction, compared to the other buildings installed at the bottom of the wadi, which have a simpler architecture, taking advantage of the natural relief and arranged summarily (huts 1-51).To the southwest of the site, at the mouth of the circus, a monumental staircase in a very advanced state of destruction remains on the gebel. A cistern (now partially destroyed) is visible below.The Michigan survey (which visited the site and drew the first plan of the remains, in 1993) reports the presence of a possible well (Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, fig. 3.160, "g") but it was not recognised as such during the MAFDO work.The site may have had two functions: a small stop on the road from Edfu to Berenike (with the possibility to host the travelers in Building 1 and to supply them with water, thanks to the tank) and a mining settlement, for the exploitation of the nearby gold vein.1 km to the west is another worker village, dated to the New Kingdom (Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 249-251) or to the Roman period (Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019). This village has not been visited by the MAFDO.

name: Abu Garahish el-Qibla
short description: New Kingdom gold miners' villages
description: The site of Abu Garahish el-Qibla is located in a depression, the wadi Umm Garahish el-Qibli, surrounded by hills, that are particularly high in the south and southwest (Gebel Buhluq, alt. 932 m) but drop in height to the north, allowing direct communication with the wadi Semna and the site of Deir el-Wikalah, 6 km away.The sites comprises two small villages, Abu Garahish el-Qibla North and South. The material (grinding mills) is dated to the New Kingdom according to Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 107-109.The MAFDO visit in 2019 was very quick and no material was seen. The remains are very scattered and few in number.The site is in a concession of the Aton company: https://www.atonresources.com/news/2017/aton-extends-the-gold-mineralized-zone-at-the-abu-gaharish-prospect-and-announces-the-discovery-of-new-au-w-cu-mineralization/

name: Abu Gerida East
short description: New Kingdom and Ptolemaic mines and settlements
description: New Kingdom and Ptolemaic mines and settlements located in a southeastern affluent of the wadi Abu Gerida, to the east of the site Abu Gerida West.This site is called Hamama I by D. and R. Klemm (Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 110-113), but the toponym Hamama does not occur on the topographical maps of the area.The location of this site is uncertain, since the settlement is not visible on satellite imagery and the published coordinates are not consistent with the description of the location.However, the description of the settlement and the mines is sufficient to localize a New Kingdom settlement reoccupied during the Ptolemaic Period, and an area of ancient gold mines to the south of the settlements. The dwellings and working facilities were partially destroyed by a modern track visible on satellite imagery.Two nearby sites described in Klemm, Klemm 2013 are not presented here since they date from the Early Arab Period (see ‚ÄúAbu Gerida‚Äù p. 109 and ‚ÄúHamama II‚Äù p. 113-114).

name: Abu Ghalqa
short description: Small Late Roman fort
description: Small Late Roman fort, badly destroyed. The surface pottery dates to the 5th and 6th c. AD.According to Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 103, the station was maybe built to replace Abu Ghusun (possible Cabalsi) located nearby, on the road to Berenike.The site was discovered by Murray in the scope of the Desert Survey in the 1920s.

name: Abu Ghusun/Cabalsi
short description: Large fort occupied in Early Roman and late Roman periods, probably  known as Cabalsi in ancient sources. Located on the Coptos-Berenike road, between Apollonos hydreuma and Novum hydreuma.
description: Large fort occupied in Early Roman and Late Roman periods, probably  known as Cabalsi in ancient sources.The fort, that has so far never been excavated and is located in the middle of the wadi Abu Ghusun, has been almost entirely destroyed by the floods, except for the eastern wall, a more than 45 m long section of which is preserved. A circular corner tower is also preserved, at the NE corner.The dating of the occupation phases is based on the analysis of the surface pottery by the Delaware survey team, that shows an occupation in the 1st and 2nd c. AD, and then from the mid-4th to the late 6th c. AD.Abu Ghusun is located around 70 km north of Berenike, on the Roman road coming from Coptos. If the identification with Cabalsi is correct (see Cuvigny 2018a, ¬ß 138-139), the fort is mentioned in Latin itineraria and an unpublished poem found at Xeron Pelagos (O.Xer. inv. 995, fr. C, 14) between the forts of Apollonos hydreuma (Gemal West) and Novum hydreuma (Abu Qurayyah), which are respectively 37 km north-west and 48 km south-east from Abu Ghusun.Cabalsi is not mentioned by Pliny, but according to Cuvigny 2018a, ¬ß 139, it is highly likely that its foundation was related to the building campaign undertaken under Vespasianus in the Eastern desert in 76/77 AD.

name: Abu Hegilig North
short description: Byzantine small station on the road to Berenike
description: Byzantine small rectangular station on the road to Berenike discovered by the Delaware survey, and named Abu Hegilig North.Apart from a possible tank and 5 rooms, the enclosure ‚Äì measuring 276 m2 ‚Äì is devoid of any construction.The scattered pottery found at the surface is dated to the late fourth and fifth centuries AD and the occupation of the site was brief, according to the Delaware survey.The station is a little off the ancient road, hidden by a low ridge. Its location was marked by a series of four cairns and "steles" atop a hill.The road station of Abu Hegilig North is dated to the very end of the functioning of the Roman road to Berenike, during the last period of intense commercial activity at the harbour. It is not located though on the shortest path from Gemal West/Apollonos hydreuma and Abu Ghusun/Cabalsi, the two main Roman stations of the area, but on the same wadi with the possible Ptolemaic and Early road station Abu Hegilig South. This may be evidence of a kind of reactivation of the Ptolemaic road in the wadi Hegilig during the Byzantine period, at the expense of wadi Umm Sayyal and Khawr Abu Hasd, where the Roman road used to be, for an unknown reason (water availability?).

name: Abu Hegilig South
short description: Small station, which includes two large tanks in its enclosure. It could be a Ptolemaic foundation, although the pottery shows that the station was mainly used in the Early Roman period.
description: Small station located in the wadi Abu Hegilig, 6.8 km to the north-west of the large Roman fort of Abu Ghusun (anc. Cabalsi?), one of the main stops on the Roman road leading from Coptos to Berenike.The surface pottery found at Abu Hegilig South dates back to the Early Roman period (Delaware survey diagnostic), which indicates that the station was in use in the 1st-2nd c. AD, probably as a satellite station of the large Abu Ghusun fort, after its foundation (maybe under Vespasianus?). The fact that the station is very close to Abu Ghusun, and not on the shortest path between Abu Ghusun and Apollonos hydreuma (Abu Qurayyah, 34.5 km to the north-west of Abu Hegilig South), the next station on the Roman road, may be due to the secondary role played by the station of Abu Hegilig South.Its location may be related to the presence of water and/or other resources.Another hypothesis could be that the small station is more ancient than the Roman road. Several pieces of evidence could support this assessment.Inside the enclosure wall are two large tanks. According to the similarity of the station's layout with other Ptolemaic stations, such as Umm Ushra, Seyhrig, Rod el-Logah, or Abu Midrik, the station may have been built in the Ptolemaic period. If that is so then the Abu Hegilig South station would have played the role that Abu Ghusun played in the Roman period on the Coptos-Berenike road, i.e. of a station between the two forts of Apollonos hydreuma and Abu Qurayyah (called Novum hydreuma in the Roman period).Sidebotham 2011b pg. 133 notes the possibility of Late Roman activity here, but this is not borne out by the pottery (J. Gates-Foster).

name: Abu Midrik
short description: Small Ptolemaic fort on the road from Edfu to Berenike
description: Small Ptolemaic fort on the road from Edfu to Berenike. Located on a flat area, thus the presence of many cairns in the vicinity, to guide the caravans.The fort, which has never been excavated, is square in shape and comprises two circular tanks. A possible well (quadrangular, of less than a meter diameter, protected by vertical slabs) was visible during the MAFDO visit in 2016, near the southern rooms.The filling inside the fort is limited, and no outside or inside dumping area has been located.An inscription (maybe funeral) was found by the MAFDO in 2016 to the south of the fort (published in Redon 2018, p. 25). It bears the name of Aristis, son of Philoxenos, a typical name from Cyrenaica.The fort was likely occupied during a short period of time, probably like Bi'r Samut, i.e. mainly in the second half of the 3rd c. BC, with construction in the second quarter of the 3rd c. BC (Redon 2018, ¬ß 25). The surface pottery dates to the 3rd c. BC (diagnostic by the Delaware survey and the MAFDO survey), which is also the date that can be given to the inscription mentioned above.To the south of the fort, a square element, which is probably an artificial feature, was identified as a hafir (water intake) by Krzywinski, Seland 2007 and Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019. However, both the situation and the orientation of the openings does not fit with this identification (Cr√©py, Redon forthcoming). Its purpose and date is unknown.

name: Abu Muawad
short description: Several New Kingdom settlements.
description: Several New Kingdom settlements described by D. and R. Klemm.

name: Abu Mureiwa
short description: New Kingdom gold settlements
description: Two settlements separated by a hill. Large waste dumps in the area are the result of wadi working.In total, there are less than 20 huts, mostly two-roomed, that were built and occupied in the New Kingdom, according to the oval mills found in the settlements.The site was reoccupied for a short time in the Early Arab Period.

name: Abu Qirayyah
short description: Small station on the Via Hadriana, dated to the late 1st-early 3rd c. AD.
description: Small fort (ca 36 x 36 m), dated to the late 1st-early 3rd c. AD, according to the diagnostic of the surface pottery by R. Tomber.A modern well is located inside the enclosure, likely reusing an ancient well location. Several rooms and a three chambered cistern are visible inside the enclosure.Although its remains are apparently well preserved, so far the fort has never been excavated, and the only thorough description is from the Delaware survey team, who visited the site in 1996.The site is located between Abu Shaar el-Qibli, a possible stop on the Via Hadriana located ca 132 km to the north, and the Safaga station, a small station, probably Roman, on the Via Hadriana, 47 km to the south. It probably served as a station on the Via Hadriana after the foundation of Antinooupolis and the construction of the road.On the contrary to the two above mentioned sites though, Abu Qirayyah was not built near the seashore but at the meeting point between the Red Sea Hills and the sandy plain that leads to the Red Sea, approximately 19 km from the sea (as the crow flies). It is located at the mouth of the wadi Abu Qirayyah  and not far from the mouth of the wadi Umm Kibash/Kebash, which leads to the Mons Claudianus (about 40 km by foot or caravan) and then to the Nile Valley.

name: Abu Qurayyah/Dios
short description: Roman fort on the road from Coptos to Berenike, ancient Dios or Iovis
description: Roman fort on the road from Coptos to Berenike, between the forts of Compasi/Daghbag (34 km)and Girf/Xeron Pelagos (40 km).The fort of Abu Qurayyah has long been identified with the ancient site of Dios (also known as Iovis in the Itinerarium Antonini, a translation of the Greek place name Dios, which refers to the god Zeus).The site (where a quarry ‚Äì of soapstone, schiste and granite ‚Äì has also been recognised) has been entirely excavated by the MAFDO, but only partially published.The fort of Abu Qurayyah/Dios is located 7 km to the north-west of the fort of Bir Bayza, founded under Vespasian. The latter was quickly abandoned, for an unknown reason (maybe a lack of water in the well?), and replaced by Abu Qurayyah, which was founded under Traianus in 115/116 AD (the date is known thanks to the discovery of the fort's dedicatory inscription, at the main gate). The fort of Abu Qurayyah was abandoned during the first half of the 3rd c. AD, as shown by the MAFDO's excavations (the last dated ostraca is from 248/249 (Philippus Arabs)).A Late Roman reoccupation was also observed, maybe due to some travelers and/or local population.

name: Abu Qurayyah/Kainon hydreuma (?)
short description: Site comprising five forts, two in the wadi, three on mountain tops, all dated to the Roman period
description: The site of Abu Qurayyah is original in that it gathers, in about the same place, five forts, two in the wadi, three on mountain tops. The larger forts are those built in the plain, along the ancient road. One of the hill forts is built near the two forts in the plain, while forts 4 and 5 are between 1 and 2 km to the east, on the northern side of a tributary wadi that leads to the Red Sea mountains.The site is about 25 km NW of Berenike, as the crow flies, at the intersection of two ancient roads, one leading from Berenike to Shealeq, Khashir, Gemal West/Apollonos hydreuma and the Nile Valley, the other to Lahmi and the Red Sea.It was mainly occupied during the Roman period, but the site could already have been in use during the Ptolemaic period, if one considers its strategical location on the final part of the road coming from the Valley and leading to Berenike, which was founded at the beginning of the Ptolemaic period. Some Ptolemaic material may have been recovered in Forts 1, 4 and 5.In the Roman period (1st-2nd c. AD), the two forts in the plain, and the three hill forts were occupied. This dense occupation is not totally understood, since the forts have not been excavated (even though they have been carefully described by the many travelers and missions who have surveyed the site). This may be due to the fact that the forts succeed one another over time. But one could also explain this large number of structures by the fact that the site was home to a large troop, as well as serving as a water supply for Berenike and to the logistics of the caravans approaching and leaving Berenike. Forts 1 and 2 are the largest and probably the place where most of the inhabitants and travelers lived. Forts 3, 4, and 5 may have had a function that was more related to road monitoring.The site of Abu Qurayyah has long been identified with Vetus Hydreuma seemingly mentioned by Pliny HN 6, 26, 103 (see Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 80). However, Cuvigny (2018a, ¬ß 140-144) recently proposed identifying the site with Kainon Hydreuma, another fort mentioned by Pliny, the Itinerarium Antonini and the Peutinger Table, and one ostracon found at Xeron Pelagos (O.Xer. inv. 995, fr. c, 15). It is the last stop before Berenike in all these lists. For H. Cuvigny, the toponym vetus hydreuma does not exist. This is a misunderstanding of Pliny's sentence, which should be understood as ‚ÄúThen (one arrives) at New Well, at 236 miles from Coptos. There exists also another well, an old one (hydreuma vetus), which is called ‚ÄòTrogodytic,‚Äô where a garrison mounts guard, two miles off the main route. It is at a distance of 7 miles from Novum Hydreuma.‚ÄùSince no fort has been excavated yet, and no written documents have been found here, these assumptions remain impossible to verify.

name: Abu Rahal East;
short description: Ptolemaic station on the road from Edfu to Berenike
description: Ptolemaic station on the road from Edfu to Berenike. It is located at the supposed junction between the two ancient roads linking Edfu to Berenike on one side and Edfu to Marsa Nachari (perhaps the ancient port of Nechesia?) on the other.The station (or fort, although the building is small and the enclosure wall not regular) is built on a hill made of sand and gravel in the middle of the wadi. It is quite well preserved and has never been excavated. The original building was probably enlarged at some point, in particular with an enclosure for protecting a well.The well that is visible today is recent (ca 1906 according to Ball 1912, p. 260), but it could be a reopening of an ancient one.No dump has been located in the vicinity.The site was likely occupied during the Ptolemaic period, probably like Bi'r Samut, Abbad, El-Kana√Øs, etc., i.e. mainly in the second half of the 3rd c. BC, with construction in the second quarter of the 3rd c. BC (Redon 2018, ¬ß 25). The surface pottery dates to the early Ptolemaic times (diagnostic by the Delaware survey and the MAFDO survey).

name: Abu Rushaid South
short description: Beryl mining settlement 2 km north of Nugrus
description: Beryl mining settlement 2 km north of Nugrus, in the district of Sikait. It is composed of a mine and a small settlement composed of a dozen huts.The site was exploited during the Early and Late Roman period, according to the diagnostic of the surface pottery by the Delaware survey.

name: Abu Shaar
short description: Major site on the Red Sea coast, Late Roman fort
description: Major site on the Red Sea coast. It had long been identified as the ancient harbour of Myos Hormos but the Ptolemaic and Roman harbour was finally, and with certainty, identified as Quseir el-Qadim in the 1990s (see B√ºlow-Jacobsen et al. 1994).The excavations of the fort of Abu Sha'ar by the university of Delaware between 1987 and 1993 show that it was erected in 309-311 AD, according to a Latin inscription. It hosted the Ala Nova Maximiana (cavalry and dromedary unit) of the Roman army for less than a century and was abandoned by the soldiers at the end of the fourth century AD.The site was reoccupied by a Christian community who left many traces on the site up until the end of the 6th c. AD.

name: Abu Shaar el-Qibli
short description: Roman fort, located ca 5 km from the Abu Shaar fort, on the Via Hadriana
description: The Roman fort of Abu Shaar el-Qibli lies 4.9 km from the seashore and the fort of Abu Shaar.It is located on the path of the Via Hadriana, some 60 km south-east of Abu Shaar el-Bahri and 57 km north-west from Abu Qurayyah.The fort is rectangular in shape and encloses an area of ca 41.60 x 49.10 m. An outside building, drawn by Wilkinson but not mentioned by the more recent works, could be a caravanserai. Finally, a channel led water from the nearby Bir Abu Shaar el-Qibli to the fort. Near the well are the remains of several basins and pipes.The University of Delaware's excavations of the fort yielded mainly pottery and two dozen ostraca. They show that the fort was built on pure sand, maybe at the beginning of the 2nd c. AD., which corresponds to the opening of the Via Hadriana.

name: Abu Shehat
short description: Small Roman station on the Qena-Mons Claudianus road
description: The site, called Abu Shehat or Talat al-Zarqa, is located in the wadi Abu Shehat, on an alluvial cone at the confluence of three wadis, partially sheltered from flooding by outcrops of the Shadli Formation.The site has been surveyed several times, in particular by the MAFDO in January 2019. The following presentation comes from the unpublished report of this visit.The main feature of the site is a circular shaft of nearly 18 m in diameter, still clearly visible, whose perimeter is delimited by blocks. A shaduf was probably located on the east side and the water was then channeled via a pipeline to a series of troughs which follow one another over a length of 50 m from west to east. To the north of the water troughs, 6 animal lines can be seen oriented N/S. In the shelter of the two alignments formed by the water troughs to the N and the pipeline to the W, which form an incomplete enclosure, stands a building consisting of 2 or 3 rooms. Next to it, is a small dump. In the main "enclosure", 1, 2 or 3 additional animal lines are visible on the satellite image but they are difficult to see on the site.  Due to the presence of a large well, troughs and animal lines, the site of Abu Shehat has all the characteristics of a station dedicated to supplying water to caravans. These caravans camped there summarily, before moving further into the desert, towards Mons Claudianus or the sea. There are very few constructions that could have sheltered the people passing through, or the inhabitants of the station (the enclosure, if it is indeed one, has only two buildings, one, one-room building, built against the pipe leading from the well to the northern drinking troughs, and the other with two or three rooms, which stands within the enclosure). It is therefore not a classic fortress, like those that equipped the roads from Coptos to Myos Hormos or Berenice, but a simple place to stopover with a well, which allowed the caravans to get water and spend the night.On the toponymy of the site, see below. The site might be identifiable with the ancient Akanthion/Akantha, or, more plausibly, with the ancient site Kampe ("the Bend").N.B.: the hypothesis put forward by R. and D. Klemm (Klemm, Klemm 2013, pp. 78-79) that the 20 m diameter round structure was a Ptolemaic washery can be refuted. This is the station shaft. Despite the filling of the upper part of the structure with a large volume of eolian sand, the deposit slopes clearly indicate the presence of a deep depression in its centre. No mining activity has been noted on the site.

name: Abu Zawal/Rayma (?)
short description: Complex site comprising several New Kingdom and Ptolemaic gold mining areas, and a Roman fort (probably anc. Rayma)
description: East of wadi Fatira, a large flat space of low altitude boarding the eastern mountains. They show that the gold mines were reopened at least once, on a large scale, before the current works.

name: Badia
short description: Roman fort in the Porphyrites district, a little off the Qena-Abu Shaar road
description: The site of Badia is not directly on the road leading to Abu Shaar and coming from Qena. It is at the intersection of the two routes which led to the Porphyrites quarries, the short one, via a zigzag pathway (8 km) through the "footpath station", and long one (32 km) via the wadi Umm Sidrah and Abu Maamal, accessible to wagons and large caravans.It comprises a large Roman fort, animal lines and a fortified rock (called Deir el-Badr), of unknown purpose.The material found during the many surveys that have visited the site and the 1990s excavations shows that it was in use when the quarries were operated. It is intrinsically linked with the Porphyrites and is called the "service station" of the Porphyrites by Maxfield, Peacock 1998, p. 184.The occupation of the zone dates to the Flavian period but the fort and the animal lines were not built before the mid-2nd century AD and postdate a little the first activities in the quarry. Their foundation is evidence of the growth of the activity and the need for a sophisticated support structure. Then, the fort was probably abandoned (during the whole 3rd c. AD ?) before being massively reoccupied in the 4th c. until the early 5th c. AD (Maxfield 2007, p. 75-80). This period of activity is probably linked with the activity in the Lykabettus quarries. However, the use of the site was also focused on the provision of food and the housing of animals, probably in relation to the Abu Shaar road. At this point, Badia gained an additionnal role as a staging post on this road. The pottery goes up to the early 5th c. AD (Maxfield, Peacock 1998, p. 192, Maxfield 2007).See Maxfield 2007 on the excavations of the dump and animal lines.

name: Barramiya

description: This site includes gold mines probably exploited since the Old or Middle Kingdom, but mainly during the New Kingdom and the Ptolemaic period.The exploitation of gold in this area required the construction of settlements during the New Kingdom and Ptolemaic periods, and the use of many stone grinding tools which were reused in the construction of modern buildings. During the Ptolemaic period, one or two large circular mills were used to crush the quartz. Large tailings result from the crushing of quartz.This site is not only a gold exploitation site, since a large rectangular building could be identified as a Ptolemaic fort. Water was provided by a well and stored in tanks.The site has been heavily and totally destroyed by modern miners, in the 2010s, but the process began long before, because of the location of the site, near the modern road, and because of the reworking of the mines, in the early 20th c. by a British company.

name: Barud/Tiberiane
short description: Small quarry and settlement 10km as the crow flies south-east of Mons Claudianus. It is well off the Via Claudiana and administered from the Mons Claudianus
description: Small quarry (ŒºŒ≠œÑŒ±ŒªŒªŒøŒΩ, metallon) and settlement 10km as the crow flies (and 15km by foot) south-east of Mons Claudianus. It is well off the Via Claudiana and administered from the Mons Claudianus.The description of Bingen is evocative: "The few soldiers guarding Tiberiane form a tiny detachment (numerus Tiberianae) of the military contingent (arithmos Porphyritou) that protects the two great quarry tracks and reports to the command stationed at the Mons Porphyrites. The Greek ostraca revealed to us that the caravan which, as we shall see, regularly transports men, food and equipment to the Mons Claudianus via Claudiana, the track coming from the Nile, eventually continues its route to Tiberiane. The impression left by the texts is that the station is no longer a pioneer in the exploitation of the desert but depends entirely on the Mons Claudianus, of which it is now only a satellite station: it is, in fact, in a state of distress for water, food, beasts of burden and in lack of protection against the Bedouins of the desert. Tiberiane returns painfully beyond the end of the world." (Bingen 2013, p. 10-11).The coarse quartz diorite extracted from the site was called marmor Tibereum (Plin. Nat. 36.55), from the ancient name of the site, Tiberiane. The stone has been identified in the floor of the Domus Tiberiana in Rome (Peacock 1997b, p. 275).A fort is located 500m from the quarries, overlooked by a skopelos. The fort is a parallelogram, with sides of ca 33m in length. It is equipped with four towers, one on each corner (one square, the others are circular). Two more towers flanked the main gate, while another, semi-circular one, is built against the south wall. The inside of the fort is entirely occupied by constructions. It is very similar to the Mons Claudianus' fort and Peacock 1997b, p. 277 proposes that they were designed by the same architect.According to Meredith, there was a bath (impossible to verify due to destruction). A tank is located near the gate, to the right. According to Peacock 1997b, p. 276, there was a well outside the enclosure.Like in the Mons Claudianus, an internal thick wall may indicate that the fort was rebuilt and enlarged (Redd√©, Golvin 1987, p. 56).In front of the gate is a trash dump.A necropolis is likely to be located in the NW of the fort, and further to the north, two mainly ruined buildings are recorded, one of which could be a smithy.The site was only discovered in 1943, by Lieutenant R. Bright, as recalled by Peacock 1997b, p. 275. Tregenza draw a first plan, and the most complete one was made by the Mons Claudianus mission that worked on the site in 1992 (survey and small trench, of 3x3m, in the dump).The occupation of the fort is dated to the mid-2nd century AD, and it was abandoned before the late 2nd c. AD. There is nothing, in the trenches opened in the fort's dump, as early as the first century AD, so the fort itself may not be contemporaneous with the initial exploitation of the stone, in the Tiberian period as indicated by the name given to the quarry (Maxfield 2003, p. 158).The quarries are located 500m to the SW of the fort. The lower quarry measures 30m long and two huts are built nearby. Two other quarries are located on the hillside, accessed via a slipway. Finally atop the hill is a cluster of three irregular stone huts and three "dolmen-like" structures, maybe for storing water and provisions, unless they were traps (Peacock 1997b, p. 278-279).

name: Belih
short description: Small fort on the road from the Porphyrites area to the Red Sea coast (where Abu Shaar was built in the Late Roman period)
description: Small fort on the road from the Porphyrites area to the Red Sea coast (where Abu Shaar was built in the Late Roman period).It might have been a station on the Qena-Porphyrites-Red Sea road in the Early Roman period, and/or linked with the Via Hadriana (the road is some km to the East).The fort is rectangular in shape and measures 28 x 25m. Its main gate is to the south and is protected by a buttress, an original feature not seen elsewhere in the desert.Inside the enclosure are at least 14 rooms (organised along the curtain wall, but with an empty space between them and the wall, as noticed by Scaife 1935). The Delaware Survey found no trace of a well or tank inside the enclosure. A recent attempt to dig a well is visible on satellite images to the north of the courtyard.According to the pottery analysis carried out by the Delaware Survey, the occupation was brief, mainly during the 1st and 2nd c. AD.N.B.: the plan presented by Redd√©, Golvin 1987, fig. 29, like the plan of Belih made by Scaife, is in fact the plan of Umm Balad (the Belih plan is pl. X of the article).

name: Berenike/Ras Banas
short description: Major harbor on the Red Sea, founded by Ptolemy II before the mid-third century BC
description: Major harbor on the Red Sea, founded by Ptolemy II before the mid-third century BC, named after his mother Berenike.For Desanges (1978, p. 271), the settlement may have been founded by the strategos Philon in the years 270 BC.A possible occupation may have occurred before the Ptolemaic period, as evidenced by the discovery of a stela dated to the Middle Kingdom on the site (see recently Hense, Sidebotham 2017 and Hense, Kaper, Geerts 2015).However, the main occupation of the site is Greco-Roman. The Ptolemaic activities are linked to Berenike's role in elephant hunting (see Thiers 2001, Sidebotham 2011, Cohen 2006, p. 320, mentioning the famous papyrus P.Petrie 2 40a dated to 224 BC that refers to elephants and Berenike in the same document). The settlement and harbor was located at the end of the Edfu-Berenike road and acted as the southernmost post of the Ptolemaic army, at the fringes of the Empire. From there, expeditions were sent by boat to the coasts of Africa, in search for the animals that were used in the Ptolemaic army to fight the Asiatic elephants of the Seleucids.Following a possible decline in the 2nd and 1st c. BC, the settlement was reactivated by the Romans. In the Roman and Late Roman period, the city played a critical role in international, regional and local commercial and cultural exchanges between Rome, the Mediterranean, Egypt, India, Africa and Arabia, as shown by the material and texts found on the site.After its final abandonment sometime prior to the middle of the sixth century AD, the site was re-discovered by Belzoni in 1818 and visited several times by scholars of the 19th and 20th c. However, proper excavations did not occur before the end of the 20th c. These were thanks to the work led by S.E. Sidebotham and W. Wendrich (from 1994 to 2001) and then by S.E. Sidebotham and I. Zych (from 2009 onward).It is absolutely impossible to summarize and present the many remains and artefacts that have been brought to light by travelers and archaeologists on the site. Two main period of occupations are distinguished here, since the role played by Berenike during the two period was not exactly the same: the Ptolemaic period, and the Roman and Late Roman period.During the Ptolemaic period, the city was mainly a harbour, equipped to host and repair the boats sent to the African coast in search of elephants. The occupation was probably limited and the remains brought to light are few.During the Roman period, the activity of the city of Berenike increased, and the city was enlarged and adorned with temples, chapels, an arch, etc. The material discovered by Sidebotham's team is incredibly rich and varied. They include documentation of 12 different written languages, varying burial customs, and diverse religious practices and culinary preferences indicating a cosmopolitan population of different ethnicities from various areas of the Mediterranean, Near East, Egypt, sub-Saharan Africa, South Arabia and South Asia.

name: Bir Abraq
short description: Fort located at 88 km (as the crow flies) from Berenike, built atop of a 50 m high hill. Its location is particularly strategic, at the intersection of a number of wadis
description: Fort located at 88 km (as the crow flies) from Berenike, built atop of a 50 m high hill. Its location is particularly strategic, at the intersection of a number of wadis.Colston and Purdy visited the site in 1874 and noticed that water was present the whole year long, in large quantities (Colston 1886, p. 526). They described the fort, whose gate is built with large blocks of local stone. Purdy copied one inscription engraved on one of the blocks. Colson 1886, p. 526 also mentions the numerous fragments of Greek inscriptions they saw inside the enclosure. G. Daressy found their sketches, including 18 drawings of the Greek inscriptions, in the archives of the Institut Egyptien (Daressy 1922). The fort is enclosed in a fortification wall of ca 160 x 98 m. It is sub-rectangular, and measures 33 x 29 m (in the middle of the walls). The wall is preserved up to 4 m high and 2 m thick where the bluff has a gentler slope.28 rooms are visible, all aligned along the curtain wall. The fort has not been excavated so its chronology and exact purpose (protection of a trade route, of water resources, of mining district, since El-Ileiga is not far) is unknown. However, the paleography of the inscriptions is Hellenistic and the surface pottery is Ptolemaic and perhaps Early Roman (Sidebotham 1996d, p. 372-377).500 m NE of the fort is an ancient well that is still in use, as well as many petroglyphs of different periods (including an elephant and a dipinto in red paint showing an elephant with a rider: Sidebotham et al. 2004, p. 152) and Late Roman pottery (impossible to see on satellite images).

name: Bir Alayyan
short description: Small unfortified station on the road from Edfu to Marsa Nakari, dated to the Ptolemaic period
description: Small unfortified way station located on the road from Edfu to Marsa Nakari (Nechesia?). The remains are composed of small structures (a square building of unknown purpose and two tanks), grouped under a steep cliff face.No well has been seen.An inscription alluding to its construction during the 28th year of Ptolemy II (258/257 BC), was found on the site:"From the river to this point, four hundred sixty-one stadioi. In the reign of Ptolemy son of Ptolemy Soter, year 28, month of Epeiph, Rhodon son of Lysimachos, from Ptolemais, toparch of the three ? , set up (this stone)" (transl. R. Bagnall, in Bagnall et al. 1996, p. 322).The Bir Alayan station was thus founded at the same moment as other stations and forts, either on the Edfu-Berenike road, or on the Edfou-Marsa Nakari road (Abbad, Bir Samut, Barramiya, etc.). The end of the site's occupation is unknown, but it could be contemporaneous with the abandonment of the main forts of the Eastern Desert (Bir Samut, Abbad) at the end of the 3rd c. BC, unless its location on the road to Marsa Nakari makes its history different and it lasted longer.The surface pottery is Ptolemaic and no Roman sherds have been seen (Bagnall et al. 1996, p. 317).

name: Bir Karim
short description: Large Ptolemaic settlement, maybe used to supply Myos Hormos with water
description: The site of Bir Karim (from the name of a modern well) is located in the wadi el-Karim, which after a bend 12 km to the E (at the foot of Gebel el-Hamadat), takes a N/S direction and connects to the current road of the wadi Hammamat (to the E of Bir al-Baydah) and to Myos Hormos /Qoseir (39 km away).The site is therefore not landlocked but connected to the ancient routes, as evidenced by the presence of two sheikhs' tombs (Ash-Shaykh Sahabi and Ash-Shaykha Amnah) just to the E. It has a well, the Bir Karim (modern, with a double well, gallows, and enclosure, doubled by a recent borehole).The ancient site of Bir Karim includes dozens of dry stone buildings on both sides of the wadi, spreading over more than 600m N/S. Some of them are well built, with large rooms, including a possible chapel in the north settlement.Only one grinding mill was seen on the site during the 2019 MAFDO survey and no gold quartz vein was visible in the vicinity (the only quartz vein seen nearby, by the Quseir el-Qadim project in 1978, contains iron: Whitcomb, Johnson 1979, p. 301). The site is thus probably not related to gold mining.Van Rengen 2018 proposes identifying Bir Karim with a Philotereion mentioned in some ostraca and which would have been located near Myos Hormos.According to Ma√´l Cr√©py, this site could have been used to provide drinking water to Myos Hormos (the area supplied water used at Qosseir during the passage of James Bruce in 1769 (Terfowey) and during the period 1864-1869 when Carl Benjamin Klunzinger lived at Qoseir).

name: Bir Minayh
short description: Multi-period activity focused on the well at Bir Minayh. Rock drawings and inscriptions, mostly early; a possible Pharaonic settlement; and a relatively large 4th-6th mining settlement or Christian laura.
description: In the wadi Minayh, multi-period activity focused around the well of Bir Minayh. Rock drawings and inscriptions, mostly early; a possible Pharaonic settlement; and a relatively large 4th-6th mining settlement or Christian laura. Rock drawings and inscriptions from the prehistoric period onward, are scattered up and down the wadi and in three small rock shelters. Considerable prehistoric rock art is present, but Old and Middle Kingdom inscriptions dominate the written material. The Pharaonic inscriptions cluster in the area around the well.  In the northeast of Bir Minayh, the Michigan survey observed Pharaonic hut footings and pottery, although a more precise date is not available. On the slopes, northwest of Bir Minayh, around 100 dry-stone structures of varying plan, associated with pottery dated to the 4th-6th centuries, are intermixed with 131 tumuli of uncertain date. This large settlement may be associated with nearby mines, although no querns or other mining items were found, or it may have been a Christian laura community. In addition to the structures are numerous cairns, watchtowers, and graves. The "Crown Peak" above the settlement on the southwester side of the wadi has two small rock shelters with drawings and inscriptions.At 3.5 west of Bir Minayh, a wall present many petroglyphs and three Roman names.

name: Bir Samut
short description: One of the major forts built during the 3rd c. BC along the road from Edfu to Berenike
description: The site of Bir Samut, visited by Belzoni in 1820 and since then frequently mentioned in travelers' accounts, was almost fully excavated by the MAFDO in 2014-2016. It was severely damaged in 2017.Bir Samut was one of the major forts in use during the 3rd c. BC along the road from Edfu to Berenike. It was probably built at the end of the reign of Ptolemy II (ca 256/255 BC, most ancient date mentioned in the ostraca).It served as a main logistical center for protecting and supplying the expeditions and caravans that crossed the desert under the reign of Ptolemy II, III and IV. It was suddenly abandoned before the end of the 3rd c. BC, probably in relation to the Theban revolt uprising.Even though the fort is located near the ancient Ptolemaic gold mining site of Samut North (4.5 km to the north), the exploitation of gold does not appear in the 1,300 or so ostraka discovered in Bir Samut and dated to its main occupation phase, except on two occasions. It was thus primarily a stopover point on the road leading to the Red Sea.Before the construction of the fort, the site was occupied in the early 3rd c. BC in relation to the exploitation of gold in the area (maybe with Samut North?).Reoccupation has also been noted, in the fort and in the surroundings, during the Roman period. Some Late Roman pottery was noticed by the Delaware survey at the periphery of the site, but it has not been associated with the fort. No Pharaonic material was found during the excavations.

name: Bir Wasif
short description: Late Roman village and several clusters of inscriptions, graffiti and marks
description: Bir Wasif corresponds to a village and several clusters of inscriptions, graffiti and marks in Wadi Wasif, near a confluence between two wadis.Dozens of dwellings (ca 120 according to Harrell et al. 2006, p. 129) can be seen on satellite imagery. According to the surface pottery, it was occupied during the 5th c. AD.The function of the village is unknown. No sign of mine or quarry exploitation has been seen in the vicinity. It could be a Christian community, like the ones that have been identified at Bir Minayh or further south, Nugrus west, Sigdit, Hetan.Like at Bir Minayh, where such a community is proposed, the village has been built on a previously occupied site, as evidenced by inscriptions and graffiti recorded in the vicinity, and dated to the reign of Darius I for one of them.

It comprises several New Kingdom sites, and a Ptolemaic processing site.A Roman and Late Roman occupation is postulated by Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 182. However it is more likely Medieval, considering the surface pottery.The site has been heavily destroyed by recent works.

name: Dawwi/El-Iteima
short description: Roman fort on the Coptos-Myos Hormos road, also called El-Iteima
description: Roman fort on the Coptos-Myos Hormos road, also called El-Iteima.The fort of Dawwi is located 154 km from Coptos and 27 km from Myos Hormos. This is the last fort on the road, after Bir Sayyalah. It has often been visited by modern travelers under various names, Dawwi, El-Iteima, Hammad, etc.The fort is still impressive, with rounded towers at each of its corners and in the middle of each of the walls of the enclosure. The chemin de ronde is still visible and accessible via several staircases. The inside of the fort is largely empty, except for a dozen rooms along the north and west wall. A large well, apparently equipped with an internal staircase, is visible in the middle of the courtyard.Only two soundings were made by the MAFDO in 1996, on the gate and outside Room 24. The material recovered during the excavations is attributable to the second half of the 2nd c. AD (Brun 2003f). The scarcity of the discoveries may evidence a short period of occupation. This is also suggested by the absence of any midden near the main gate (the area has not been destroyed by floods, so this absence is certain).According to Brun 2003f, the plan is original, with no interior rooms at first, before they were added in a second stage. This could have been a caravanserai, before its transformation into a fort. Whatever its function, its main purpose was probably to host a well. The reason for its late construction (the road was equipped in the first c. AD, and reinforced in the early 2nd c. AD) could have been a rationalization effort on the road, because the only stop, between Bir Sayyalah and Myos Hormos, until then was the fort of Nakheil, which was not on the main road, and was only accessible after a detour of more than 10 km. However, the fort of Dawwi was only briefly used, and was quickly abandoned during the 2nd c. AD, for an unknown reason, maybe due to the lack of water (Brun 2003f, p. 135).An isolated tower is located to the south-west of the fort, on a hill.

name: Deir el-Atrash
short description: Major Roman fort on the Porphyrites road
description: Deir el-Atrash is a major Roman fort, located in the wadi of the same name: it is on the way from Qena to the world-famous quarries of the Porphyrites, then Abu Sha'ar on the Red Sea coast, after this fort was founded in the Late Roman period. It is one of the largest forts in the region (55 x 55 meters).The site comprises a Roman fortress, which was reoccupated during the Late Roman period, an outside building that belongs to the so-called "animal lines" category to the east, a dump to the south of the fort's entrance and a hydraulic device (cistern, tank and series of troughs) to the west.The fort may be identified with the ancient praesidium of Melan Oros (the praesidium of the "black mountain") according to Cuvigny 2018, ¬ß 160.The long contribution of Sidebotham, Zitterkopf and Riley 1991 is a compilation of the information given by the travellers who have visited the fort since the 19th century. The MADFO launched the site's excavations in 2020. Two main phases of occupation were identified: an early 2nd century  AD one and a late 4th-early 5th century one, according to the material culture. This has to be confirmed by future work.

name: Deir el-Wikalah
short description: Roman fort built to facilitate and control access to the stone quarry of Wadi Umm Wikalah/Ophiates
description: The Roman fort of Deir el-Wikalah was built to facilitate and control access to the stone quarry of Wadi Umm Wikalah (located ca 2.1km to the north of the fort, see SIT1912), also known as Mons Ophiates in the ancient sources. There is a large filled well within the enclosure. Apart from the Roman fort, two damaged buildings, a cemetery and a tower are described.

name: Dweig/Phalakron
short description: Roman fort, on the road from Koptos to Berenike, anc. Phalakron
description: Roman fort, partly excavated by the MAFDO in 2010, located on the road from Koptos to Berenike, 32 km to the south-east of Xeron Pelagos, and 41 km to the north-west of Apollonos hydreuma/Gemal West.The fort is built at the confluence of the wadi Dweig and a small tributary descending from the nearby mountain. It is very well preserved (probably the best-preserved fort of the Eastern Desert), up to 3 meters high. It measures 29 x 25 m (725 m2), and is equipped with 4 circular towers, one at each corner. The "chemin-de-ronde" is still preserved and accessible thanks to several staircases.The foundation of the fort is not precisely dated but it could be dated to the early 2nd c. AD, although the major part of the material recovered during the 2010 excavations dated from the second half of the 2nd c. AD. It was probably abandoned during the third century, like the majority of the forts on the Berenike road, but maybe a little earlier than the forts of Xeron, Dios and Didymoi.The site was probably the ancient Phalakron, mentioned as early as 102/103 or 121/122 AD (Cuvigny 2018a, ¬ß 134), and then in the Itin. Anton. and Tab. Peut. The fact that the site is mentioned only once in the ostraca recovered in the nearby site of Xeron is unexplained. Only one other ostracon (see above) mentions the site, which may indicate the limited importance of the fort in the networks, even though this could also be due to a lack in documentation.Only a few ostraca were recovered at Dweig during the MAFDO's one-season of work in the fort (during which 8 rooms and the gate were excavated).To the east of the fort is a small and lower construction, which has been identified as a xenodochion (hotel) by the MAFDO, and which has not been excavated. No dump has been found outside the fort, probably due to wadi flooding.

name: Edfu
short description: City in the Nile Valley, ancient Behdet and Apollinopolis Magna.
description: City in the Nile Valley, ancient Behdet and Apollinopolis Magna. It was occupied from the Old Kingdom to the Byzantine period. Edfu was the capital of the second Upper Egyptian nome.The site is included here because the city had clear and direct relationships with sites in the Eastern Desert, in particular during the Pharaonic and Ptolemaic period. During the Ptolemaic period, it hosted a garrison and detachments from this garrison probably served in the forts along the road to Berenice (Bir Samut, for example).

name: El-Alam
short description: Late Roman cemetery
description: Late Roman cemetery according to Sidebotham 2011b, p. 132. It is not visible on satellite images.

name: El-Amboot North
short description: Mining site, likely Ptolemaic
description: Mining site, likely Ptolemaic, located in an area where water was largely available (Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 220). It comprises a well, probably ancient, and several huts, gathered in two clusters, to the south and west of the well.Near the well were very large tailings, certainly ancient, that were removed by modern miners before the Klemms' survey. The Klemms saw a large amount of Ptolemaic stone mills, as well as round mills from a later reoccupation (Late Roman/Early Medieval).The site was therefore a large gold processing site in Antiquity. Very few remains are visible on satellite images, mainly clusters of huts. No mine has been observed in the vicinity, thus the quartz may have come from the nearby site of El-Amboot South.

name: El-Amboot South
short description: Ancient mining site, not dated
description: Ancient mining site reoccupied by a modern mine prospected by the Hawari Company in the 1940s (Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 221).Because of this modern reoccupation, the ancient site is badly damaged. It comprises a settlement, with a dozen of one roomed-huts, a vein, and a cluster of circular anomalies, that could be huts or tombs.The site has not been dated (no tools or pottery were recorded by the Klemms), but a Ptolemaic date is possible, like at El-Amboot North.

name: El-Aras
short description: First stop on the roads leading from Qena to the Mons Claudianus and the Porphyrites
description: The site of El-Aras is 21 km away from Qena, and is de facto the first stop on the roads leading from Qena to the Mons Claudianus, and the Porphyrites. It is also located on the possible road to Safaga, through Qirayyah, Semna, etc.It was discovered by Murray in the scope of the Desert Survey in the 1920s. He found burnt bricks near the modern well (brackish). Meredith and Tregenza visited the site and Tregenza draw a rough plan, showing a small "camp" with round corners, built in mudbricks with a well in its courtyard, and two outside wells (the "Roman well" and the "lower well"). To the north, animal lines are conjectured.On the satellite images, the shape of the oval feature is visible, but the animal lines, if they ever existed, are now totally destroyed by recent works. The oval feature is ca 14 x 8m. Sidebotham et al. 1991, p. 595 writes that the plan of the fort is approximately square and measures ca 44 x 48m. It implies that the "camp" of Tregenza is in fact the animal lines that were also drawn by Sidebotham et al. 1991, fig. 24.Several modern wells are visible, but not the wells seen by Tregenza.The chronology of the site's occupation is vague, 1st to 4th c. AD from the analysis of the surface pottery by the Delaware University. It is sure that it was occupied in the Roman period, when the roads from Qena were in use.

name: El-Eleiga
short description: Gold mining settlement, probably exploited in the Ptolemaic period, and reoccupied in the Early Medieval Period
description: The site of El-Eleiga is located on a trade road from Berenike to Aswan, via Bir Abraq.It is a gold mining site, probably exploited in the Ptolemaic period, and reoccupied in the Early Medieval Period, according to the surface pottery found, and the presence of rotative mills (Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 276). Two cemeteries are also recorded, as well as Predynastic graffiti. Their presence could show that the site was exploited during that period. This is explained by the fact that the gold was easily accessible in the form of nuggets that could have been freely obtained without subterranean mining or extensive panning.It consists of several open pit hole mines, several hundreds of huts, tailings and a large 155 m long housing complex. The majority of the remains are probably dated to the Medieval period, although it is difficult to certify since the site has never been excavated. This is why only one subsite was created, for the Ptolemaic occupation, centered on the housing complex.

name: El-Faysaliyya/Xeron Pelagos
short description: Large Roman fort on the Coptos-Berenike road
description: Roman fort on the Coptos-Berenike road, named Xeron Pelagos ("the Dry Sea") in Antiquity.The fort is well preserved and was excavated by the MAFDO during 3 campaigns. Two outside buildings are notable, probably acting as hospitalia. A necropolis has also been studied. A tower is known in the vicinity, probably for ensuring the road traffic was secure.According to the pottery, coin and ostraca finds, the construction of the fort of Xeron occurred during the first century AD, maybe at the same time that the fort of Dios, Siket and Aphrodites Orous were built, in 76/7 AD. It was occupied during a longer span of time than the majority of the road forts of the Eastern Desert, until the mid-third century AD.The later phase of occupation yielded an interesting bunch of ostraca, recording bread distribution to Blemmyes (see Cuvigny 2014d).A thorough description of the evolution of the occupation of the fort is to be found in Brun 2015, pending the final publication of the excavations carried out by the MAFDO in 2011, 2012 and 2013.

name: El-Ghorban
short description: Hollow ways, sherd scatters, animal tracks. Ptolemaic and Roman.
description: Gebel el-Ghorban area, surveyed by the Michigan team in Feb. 1993, as a walking assessment of the vicinity of the installations at Umm Qaria/ Umm Ushra. The area seems to have seen traffic, primarily in the the Ptolemaic period but also in the Late Roman/Byzantine. The survey team found two hollow ways partly obscured by later animal tracks, one Ptolemaic and one Roman, passing to the north of the peak of Gebel el-Ghorban  (24 39.25 N 34 31.71 E) in the Wadi Umm Ushra/ Umm Qaria area (SIT0225). The two tracks were probably less-used alternate passes, with the Roman iteration being adapted to the needs of camels. In this area there are also several undated cairns and wells, as well as two sets of serpentine features that may be built or natural. The surveyors judged that if they were built features they were pre-Hellenistic.

name: El-Hammamat (quarries)
short description: Quarries, inscriptions, and a small Roman settlement.
description: Of the explorations of the Egyptian expedition (1798-1801), only the one led by Bachelu passed through the area, but no mention was made of quarries or inscriptions. The quarries themselves were the source of "bekhen" stone, exploited from the Predynastic through the Roman periods.  Harrell describes eastern and western quarries. Several areas are densely inscribed by the workmen, officers, and scribes who were involved in the quarrying operations. Other inscriptions are traveler's graffiti left by individuals on the Nile-Red Sea route. The most intensely inscribed area of the site is the Paneion, a gallery on the south side of the wadi with hundreds of inscriptions and figural scenes mostly dedicated to Min or Pan (as well as Isis, Ptah, Harpocrates, and Amun). These are mainly of Pharaonic to Roman date. Directly across from the Paneion, built against the north wall of the wadi, is the small Roman settlement, a complex of contiguous rooms that could have served as dormitories for quarry workers. In the northern central part of this complex is a large chapel with a stone naos bearing a dedicatory inscription to Tiberius. Harrell and Goyon identify the central part of the site (Paneion and village) with the "Shrine of Amun of the Pure Mountain" marked on the New Kingdom Turin papyrus, but the excavations of Annie Gasse in the 1980s showed no traces of a New Kingdom building in this area.

name: El-Hamra
short description: Roman fort on the Coptos-Myos Hormos road, located between the forts of El-Zarqa/Maximianon and Bir Sayyalah
description: Large Roman fort on the Coptos-Myos Hormos road, located between the forts of El-Zarqa/Maximianon (12 km to the west) and Bir Sayyalah (10 km to the east).For some reason the fort has been neglected by the travelers and missions who worked in the desert, although it is well preserved, and located near the modern road (and thus easily accessible).Only one excavation campaign has been carried out, in 1996 by the French MAFDO. The gate was cleared, and one building inside the courtyard was excavated.The material discovered by the MAFDO was scarce (and the midden has gone). No chronological data is given in Redd√© 2003b; the fort is Roman and the material published in the chapter (costrels) date to the 2nd century AD. More details are given in Brun 2003g, which states that the material is dated to the mid-2nd c. or second half of the 2nd c. AD. In view of the similarity of the plan of El-Hamra with Bir el-Hammamat, Brun 2018, ¬ß 18 suggests that they were built at the same time, during the second quarter of the 2nd century.It is surprising to find such a large fort so close to the fort of Maximianon, which has the same dimensions (over 50 m in length). Only larger excavations could give clues to explain this. In the present state of our knowledge, the most obvious reason would be a difference in the chronology of the forts, Maximianon and Bir Sayyalah, which may be identical to the ancient Simiou (see Cuvigny 2018a, ¬ß 120), being built during a first building programme in the Vespasianic era, while El-Hamra was built afterwards, during the second century AD, in connection with an increase in traffic on the road, or a lack of water in one or the two other forts.

name: El-Heita
short description: Large Roman fort on the road from Qena to the Porphyrites, and smaller fort on a hill
description: Large fort with a large reservoir and a well (dry when visited by Murray in the 1920s). Animal lines are also located to the west of the station, as well as a smaller fort located on a hill.The buildings are all built in mudbricks, on a rubble foundation.Under the Principate, the wadi fort was the meeting point between the Porphyrites and Claudianus routes, but the remains of the Early Roman period are largely covered by the late fort, which was still in use during the 4th c. when Abu Shaar, the maritime head of the road, was founded. The chronology of the second fort is unknown (only a few pieces of pottery have been found) but it is likely contemporaneous, at least to one of the wadi fort's periods of occupation.Scaife mentions the presence of cairns between el-Aras and el-Heita, at regular intervals (1935, p. 64: 3 pairs, 3 single ones, and possibly 1 and 2 more).Sidebotham 2011b pg. 130 suggests possible 6-7th c. activity.

name: El-Hisinat
short description: Settlements and quartz mines
description: In this area, gold was exploited during the Old/Middle Kingdom, the New Kingdom and the Ptolemaic Period, according to the tools found near the mines.The traces of New Kingdom occupation can also be seen in three settlements, in the north, south and southeast of the site.

name: El-Hudi
short description: Amethyst mines and forts from the Middle Kingdom and the Roman Period.
description: The site of El-Hudi is located 35 km southeast of Aswan, near the Gebel el-Hudi overlooking the Wadi el-Hudi.The area is composed of over 30 subsites dated from the Predynastic Period to the Arab Period and identified by Ahmed Fakhry in the 1940s and by the American Wadi el-Hudi Expedition led by Kate Liszka since 2014.Most of the studied remains are dated from the Middle Kingdom and the Roman Period.El-Hudi is famous for the amethyst mines, the only active ones in Egypt during the Middle Kingdom. They were also exploited during the Roman Period.The extraction of minerals required the construction of buildings to shelter the workers and store the amethyst. Several fortified camps were built next to the mines. More than 150 inscriptions have been engraved on stelas and boulders, but many of them have been removed since the discovery of the site in the 1920s.

name: El-Kanais
short description: Major site of the southern part of the Eastern desert, occupied in the New Kingdom (well and temple) and Ptolemaic period (road station and Paneion)
description: Major site of the southern part of the Eastern desert. The site of El-Kanais was already frequented in Predynastic times as indicated by the presence of graffiti and flints in the area. A text dated to the time of Amenhotep III shows that the location was crossed during the 18th Dynasty, but it is during the 19th Dynasty that the place takes on a particular importance with the construction of a temple linked to the digging of a well.Then, a fortress was built during the Ptolemaic period. It is not sure whether the site remains a fortress after the abandonment of the Ptolemaic road from Edfu to Berenike's main forts (Bir Samut, Abbad). However, the site has been constantly reoccupied by travelers, on their way to or from Berenike in the Late Ptolemaic and Roman period. They left many inscriptions on the rock in which the temple is cut, which has served for inscriptions and graffiti since the Predynastic period.According to Murray 1925, p. 145, the present well (55 m deep) was bored by the Egyptian Mines Department in 1906 and lined with stones from the ancient hydreuma.

short description: Roman fort, first station on the Coptos-Myos Hormos road
description: Roman fort, first station on the road from Coptos to Myos Hormos. An alignment of additionnal buildings is interpreted as a garrison, and a watchtower and a small fortified complex is also noted, at the southern border of the site.The quartz vein was not located by D. and R. Klemm during their survey.The Roman dating suggested by the Klemm comes from the fact that grinding mills from the Ptolemaic period have been reused in the masonry of the buildings. However, this is also attested in the Ptolemaic station at Bir Samut, and the Ptolemaic mining village at Ghozza, both dated to the 3rd c. BCE. They are dated from the Middle Kingdom to the Graeco-Roman period.

name: Gasus
short description: Site with a well and four buildings, dated to the Ptolemaic and Roman period, with a Middle Kingdom occupation also attested. Likely a stop on the road from the sea to the desert, via the wadi Gasus
description: Site located 8km from the sea and the site of Marsa Gawasis. It is located in the wadi Gasus, a parallel to wadi Safaga and an entrance into the desert from the Red Sea.It comprises five subsites: a well, surrounded by an enclosure and that is likely ancient; and a so-called station, composed of four buildings (Western, Middle, Southern and Eastern buildings, from the labels given by Sayed 1977), built on a terrace. They are not enclosed by walls, do not follow the same orientations and their relationship is not obvious. They are built with different techniques and material and may not all be contemporaneous.According to Sayed 1977, the Western building is a chapel (two reused Pharaonic inscriptions were found inside), and the Southern one a bath, but he put forward few arguments to prove this. The Eastern building is the largest one, and is similar to a small station or rest-house.The pottery on the surface is very mixed (due to recent vandalism) and dated to the Middle Kingdom (20% of the finds) Hellenistic and Roman period (80% according to Bragantini et al. 2018, p. 10). It probably means that the availability of water attracted people to the place, from the Middle Kingdom onward and that the majority of the buildings are dated to the Hellenistic and/or Roman period.See SIT1780 for a description of the well.

name: Gemal West/Apollonos hydreuma
short description: Large area with many subsites. The main one is a large Ptolemaic  (?) and Roman fort, known as Apollonos hydreuma in the ancient sources
description: Large area with many subsites. The main one is a large Ptolemaic  (?) and Roman fort, known as Apollonos hydreuma ("the well of Apollo") in the ancient sources. It has been largely destroyed, but was certainly one of the largest Roman forts in the Eastern Desert.The ancient place name of the site appears first in the list of hydreumata (wells and, more broadly, stops with water) known on the road from Coptos to Berenike, before the large building programme that took place under Vespasian (HN 6.102). The toponym may also appear on one Ptolemaic ostracon found at Bir Samut (O.Sam. inv. 720) that, if it is this toponym, would show that the station was already in use in Ptolemaic times (Cuvigny 2018a, ¬ß136). The surface pottery is only Roman, but since the fort was probably in use for a long period (thus the stratigraphy is probably thick and the Ptolemaic material buried under Roman and Late Roman date layers), and its remains are largely destroyed, only an excavation could secure a foundation in the Ptolemaic period.The other subsites are mining villages and a necropolis, all occupied in the Roman and sometimes Late Roman period. They have all been named Gemal West + a precision about their relative position to the fort, while some of them are sometimes labeled, in the bibliography, with another toponym (the north settlements are sometimes called Kabb Marfua, the southeast Geli, etc., see toponymy).

name: Ghadir
short description: Ptolemaic gold mining settlement
description: Ptolemaic gold mining settlement, composed of at least 7 clusters along the edges and terraces of the wadi Ghadir, over a distance of about 3.5 km. The Klemms did not find the quartz veins that were mined by the inhabitants of the settlement.In the SW village, Ptolemaic concave mills and apron-shaped runner stones are reused in nomadic graves (between 20 and 30 graves) that are built above the huts. The other important cluster (to the NE) is better preserved, even if there are also traces of reoccupation.(From Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 262-263).The Klemms date the sites to the Ptolemaic period according to the presence of Ptolemaic grinding mills. According to Government 2004, the NE village dates to the Roman period, while the SW is Late Roman (4th to 6th c. AD). If the settlement is related to gold exploitation, a Roman occupation is unlikely and we propose to date the whole site to the Ptolemaic period, with a possible Late Roman reoccupation, materialised in particular by the graves, in the SW village. This reoccupation could also be related to gold exploitation in the Late Roman period, as it is the case in many other Eastern Desert sites (see Umm Fawakhir for example).

name: Ghozza/Berkou
short description: Ptolemaic gold mining settlement and Roman fort
description: In the wadi el-Ghozza, about 100 km from Qena, in a fairly open plain and an area of successive confluences with four small tributaries (two on the right bank, two on the left bank); the wadi el-Ghozza connects to the W at the wadi el-Atrash (from N/S dir.), at the location of the archaeological site known as Bab el-Mukhenig (8 km away).  The site includes a Roman fort to the north-west, a Ptolemaic miner village to the south-east of the fort, and some isolated buildings to the west and north-east of the fort, dated to the same period.A large facility, for hydraulic purposes, and gold mines are located in the same area.The ancient name of the site is Berkou (according to several ostraca found on site in 2020 by the MAFDO). The site owes its existence to the presence of gold mines in the vicinity, which may have attracted miners in the New Kingdom (two New Kingdom millstones are still visible in the courtyard of the fort) and especially in the Ptolemaic period.The site was later reoccupied in Roman times by a fort founded in the early High Empire, perhaps as early as the first half of the 1st century AD. It is linked to the opening of the Porphyrites' quarry, as demonstrated by several mentions in ostraca. The fort was abandoned relatively quickly, at the end of the 1st / beginning of the 2nd century AD, perhaps to be replaced by the neighbouring fort of Deir el-Atrash which is located on a much more convenient route for reaching the Porphyrites.According to Cuvigny 2018a, the road passing through Ghozza also leads to the diorite quarry of Umm Shejilat (18 km from Qattar), exploited in the 1st / 2nd century AD.

name: Gidami
short description: Gold mining settlement dated to the Ptolemaic period, with a possible New Kingdom occupation and Roman reoccupation
description: The site is in the wadi el-Gidami, at the confluence between the latter and a secondary wadi leading from the north. It is dominated to the northwest, northeast and south by relief peaking at 700m.A well, the Bir Sirbakis, is clearly visible (and still exploited) in the western part of the valley. The NF 36 K1d map proposes the toponym Sirbakis for the shaft and the mines; the archaeological remains are designated as "Ruins (Roman)". Meredith and others called the site Eradiya or Aradiya, but it seems more accurate to name it Gidami, like the Klemms, since it is located in the wadi Gidami.The ancient site of Gidami is composed of a miners' village, with many grinding tools visible on the surface, and a very impressive ancient mine, all dated to the Ptolemaic period. A Roman reoccupation is evidenced by the surface pottery. A New Kingdom one is hypothetised by the Klemms, but it was not seen in the field during the MAFDO survey in 2019.Nowadays the site belongs to a mining company which has apparently carried out exploration and is guarding the site (Aton Ressources Inc.). In addition, the site was intensively exploited in the years 1950-2000. The remains of this modern installation are very interesting and well preserved.E.A. Floyer described the place and its important water resources, but he did not mention any of the archaeological remains.
