name: Kalalat
short description: Two Roman forts located 8.5 km SE of Berenike, at 1.5 km distance from each other
description: Two forts located 8.5km SE of Berenike. They are located 1.5km from each other.The large fort, located to the SW, measures ca 90 x 80m, i.e. more than 70ha. This is one of the most important forts in the Eastern desert. It is defended by 9 towers, two on each side of the gate (which is to the west), four (one on each of the corners), and one in the middle of the N, E and S walls. A large well (unless it is a tank, as it is sometimes claimed) is very visible in the center of the courtyard. It is protected by a wall and accessed by a staircase. The well is connected to a tank (divided into two parts) by a canalization. The fort is largely covered by sand so the interior rooms are not clearly visible, but they are likely to be built against the curtain wall. At least 8 staircases, that access the parapet of the enclosure,  are recorded by Wilkinson on his plan. Several trenches were opened in the fort by the Berenike project in 1997 and 1998. The surface pottery dates from the 1st-second AD and 5th/6th AD, while the material recovered during the excavations is only dated to the 1st/2nd c. AD. (no later than Trajan) (Sidebotham and Barnard 2000, p. 395-397). The fort was thus quickly abandoned after its construction, probably under Vespasian, like the Siket fort, also located in the vicinity of Berenike.The smaller fort measures 26 x 32m (ext. dim.). It is rectangular and comprises 6 circular towers, two on both sides of the gate and four at the corners. No visible well is recorded by the travellers or the archaeologists that worked on the site. A trench was opened by the Berenike Project in the gate of the small fort of Kalalat in 2000. No dedicatory inscription was found but the material and stratigraphy show that it had only one phase of occupation from the mid-2nd to mid-4th c. AD. Surface pottery may indicate that the site was visited before and after that date, but there are very few sherds.The purpose of the two forts of Wadi Kalalat was probably the developement and protection of a potable water supply for Berenike. However, the two forts were abandoned before the city, maybe because of problems finding water (Haeckl 2007, p. 356). They also formed a defensive ring for Berenike, with a dozen other forts (Sidebotham 2018, p. 11).

name: Khashm el-Minayh/Didymoi
short description: Major Roman fort on the Coptos-Berenike road
description: Roman fort built on a small hill in the middle of the wadi Minayh, 2 to 5m above the wadi level.It is located on the Roman road from Coptos to Berenike, 26.7 km south-east of Qusur el-Banat and 32 km north-west of Minayh el-Hir/Aphrodites Orous.The large Roman fort of Khashm el-Minayh was known during Antiquity under the name of Didymoi, which refers to its tutelary deities, the Dioscuri, invoked by its occupants in their private letters, although the material from the chapel shows that the main god was, as it had been in the whole region since Trajan, Zeus Helios Megas Sarapis.Two phases of occupation are identified both in the stratigraphy of the middens and in the ostraca: the first one starts in 76/77 AD when the fort was built (as shown by the dedicatory inscription I.Did. 1), at the same time as other forts on the desert roads, such as Minayh el-Hir or Siket near Berenike, at the instigation of the prefect Iulius Ursus. Then the fort was abandoned around 150 AD, and renewed in 176/177 AD (date of the inscription I.Did. 3), the year following Marcus Aurelius' stay in Alexandria. The fort was finally abandoned around 250 AD. The abandonment of the fort was probably linked with the collapse of its well.Between the two phases, several differences are visible in the material and texts (official documents are mainly attested during Phase 2 while private letters are more numerous during Phase 1), as well as in the form of occupation (the outside middens were no longer used at the end of the fort's occupation, rubbish was thrown in the abandoned parts of the enclosure). This could indicate a shift in the administration of the road, which seemed to be more militarized during the first period, while nomads and slaves were more involved in the logistic of the road in the later period.The fort, like many other forts, was still visited by travelers and shepherds during the Late Roman period.For a thorough description, from the MAFDO's 1997-2000 excavations of the fort, see Cuvigny 2011a and 2012b.

name: Kurdumai
short description: Late Roman or Medieval gold mining settlement
description: Gold mining settlement, with an exploited quartz vein (that is more than 100m long) and a cluster of about 60 structures, according to Government 2004, p. 160. The Klemms saw 20-25 small round huts. Dated to the Roman period by the Government 2004, and to the Early Arab period by the Klemms (Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 221), due to the presence of round mills and anvil stones. However, a Late Roman occupation cannot be excluded as round mills already existed in the late Roman period.The mine was reworked by a British Company at the beginning of the 20th c. The satellite views show hundreds of recent workings in the area, probably caused by the proximity of the large mine of Sukkari (7km to the north).

name: Lahmi
short description: Ptolemaic station
description: Ptolemaic station, reused in the Roman period.The site of Lahmi was reportedly discovered by Murray in the scope of the Desert Survey in the 1920s, although it is mentioned in Lesquier in 1918 and was thus already known before Murray's publication. It has been carefully surveyed by the Delaware team, who visited the site five times in the 2000s and 2010s.From the surface pottery, the station is dated to the Early Ptolemaic to Early Roman period, with an interruption in the Late Ptolemaic period.It is located at the intersection of three roads, one coming from the Red Sea shore, another from El-Khashir and a third one from Abu Qurayyah (maybe the ancient Kainon hydreuma). It is not situated on an ancient major road (the road from Coptos and Edfu to Berenike passed by El-Khashir and Abu Qurayyah), and probably had another function in the Berenike network than as a road station to the Nile Valley, maybe in relation to the supply of water and security matters.The station seems to have been reoccupied, maybe briefly, in the Late Ptolemaic/Early Roman period, and then abandoned, and Sidebotham 2001b pg. 133 suggests the possibility of 4th c. activity. Despite the fact that the site of Lahmi is particularly well located between the Red Sea shore and Berenike, the Via Hadriana did not reuse the site as a stop when it was built in the 130s AD.

name: Laqeita/Phoinikon
short description: Roman fort with wells, located at the crossing of the roads leading from Coptos to Berenike and Myos Hormos and thus of critical importance
description: Roman fort with wells, now totally destroyed. Located at the crossing of the roads leading from Coptos to Berenike and Myos Hormos and thus of critical importance.The presence of water in abundance (with probable artesian wells) in this small oasis is surely the reason for this station. As in the case of Abbad, at the mouth of the Edfu-Berenike road, Laqeita/Phoinikon played a crucial role in the supply and preparation of caravans before the start of their journey through the desert.The inscription found in the station that is dated to the reign of Claudius shows that it was among the first stations equipped in the desert under Roman rule.A Ptolemaic occupation is not proved. However, the presence of water in abundance on the way from Coptos to the wadi Hammamat and the Ptolemaic gold mines of Umm Fawakhir and Atalla strongly suggest that the site may have been already known and used before the Roman period.

name: Luxor
short description: City in the Nile Valley, ancient Waset and Thebes or Diospolis Magna.
description: City in the Nile Valley, ancient Waset and Thebes or Diospolis Magna.The site is included here because the city had relationships with sites in the Eastern Desert. It was the administrative center of Upper Egypt from the Middle Kingdom to the Late Period, the capital of the country during the 18th dynasty of the New Kingdom, and the center of a theocratic kingdom during the Third Intermediate Period.

name: Maghrabiya
short description: Roman quarrying site for gabbro exploitation
description: Roman quarrying site for gabbro exploitation (the Delaware survey distinguished 4 varieties of gabbro). This is located ca 18km from Abu Gerida west.In the Wadi Maghrabiya there are three buildings built in stone:- The E building is built along a hill, and comprises eight rooms. It measures ca 27.2 x 5.65m.- The NW building has 5 rooms and measures 19.8 x 6.05m.- The SE building consists of 6 rooms with an overall dimension of ca 10.65 x 7.75m.These buildings served as dwellings and probably as places for storing food for the workers working in the quarries.The quarries (at least 12 were recorded by the Delaware survey) are located to the south and can be accessed via a ramp. (from Sidebotham 1996a, p. 189).

name: Marsa Dabr
short description: Small fort on the Via Hadriana, also called Marsa el-Nabi el-Sogheir, near the Red sea
description: Small fort on the Via Hadriana, also called Marsa el-Nabi el-Sogheir. It was almost entirely destroyed in 1996 when surveyed by the University of Delaware. Murray claims that he found it during his survey in the early 1920s.Square in shape, the station measures ca 40 x 39 m. No hydraulic device was seen during the survey, but a well or a cistern was probably hosted in the middle of the enclosure.The pottery found on the surface was scarce and non-diagnostic.

name: Marsa Gawasis
short description: Major harbor of the Middle Kingdom, with traces of a first installation at the end of the Old Kingdom, and a short reoccupation during the New Kingdom. A Ptolemaic occupation is sometimes hypothesised
description: Sayed's excavations in the 1970s and Bard and Fattovich's excavations from 2001 to 2011 revealed a Middle Kingdom harbor, with traces of a first installation at the end of the Old Kingdom, and a short reoccupation during the New Kingdom.The harbor was located on the northern shore of a lagoon that has been filled by sand and does not exist anymore.The main purpose of this harbor was to send expeditions to Punt.Before the excavations, Murray identified this site as the Ptolemaic harbor of Philoteras [SIT1461] (Murray 1925, p.142), but only because of the coordinates given by Ptolemy. He did not see any archaeological remains.In 1951, Tregenza found two inscriptions in Greek and hieroglyphic (Tregenza 1958, p. 182-183), which led Meredith to conclude that the hypothesis of Murray was right (Meredith 1952, p. 105). However, no traces of Ptolemaic occupation were found during the excavations.Two maps call this site ‚ÄúPhiloteras‚Äù: the 1:250 000 ‚ÄúNG 36-7‚Äù and the ‚ÄúTabula Imperii Romani Coptos‚Äù of Meredith.

name: Marsa Nakari
short description: Ptolemaic and early Roman harbor on the Red Sea; could be the ancient Nechesia
description: The remains of the site of Marsa Nakari are scarce. It is enclosed by a wall (ca 52 x 103m), with at least one gate to the south, and one to the north, towards the sea (Seeger 2001, p. 79). Inside the enclosure there is a sub-rectangular building (ca 22m large and at least 42m long) and other small structures.Other buildings, some of which have curved walls, are located outside of the enclosure. To the south are several small mounds that could be trash dumps.A Ptolemaic/Early Roman and a Late Roman occupation were evidenced by the work of the ARCE-Univ. Northern Arizona mission between 1999 and 2002.The site stands on a bluff right by the sea, near a small cove that may have been used as a port.The site has been tentatively identified by S. Sidebotham with Nechesia, one of the Ptolemaic foundations on the Red Sea, mentioned by Claudius Ptolemy 4.5.8 (see also SIT1459 for the ancient sources about Nechesia). The site lies at the extremity of the Edfu-Red Sea road that he and his team surveyed in 1996-1997, which gives weight to this hypothesis, since the majority of the stops on the road are dated to the Ptolemaic period.Eastern Desert Ware was found at Marsa Nakari, which probably shows the presence of Beduin populations (Blemmyes?) on the site (Barnard 2004-2005).The remains attributable to each phase are not easy to distinguish. It has thus been decided to create an "unknown phase" for the remains, and two phases for the material.

name: Marsa Shuni
short description: Small station, not dated
description: The site was first seen by De Castro in 1541. According to his guides (both "natives inhabitants" and "Moors") "there formerly stood a famous city of the Gentiles" that Joan De Castro thought to be Nechesia.According to Couyat 1910b, p. 528, there was a small station similar to the one in the wadi Safaga. It was identified as Albus Portus by Wilkinson (unpublished), or as Nechesia by Couyat (1910b, p. 528) but Murray does not agree: "There is certainly a small quadrangular ruin at Shuni but the anchorage is very small and there is no water" (Murray 1925, p. 142).According to the Michigan University survey in December 1993, the site is Medieval, and porcelaine dated to the Song period (11th-13th c.) was recovered on the surface (Orientalia 1997, p. 329).An unpublished drawing by Wilkinson (MSS xxx) shows the harbour and a town located on the shore, but no mentions of Antiquities. The town drawn by Wilkinson is not visible on the satellite images and has probably been destroyed by the construction of the modern road. Nothing that could be a station or other remains are visible on the satellite images.

name: Middle Sikait
short description: Beryl mining settlement, occupied in the Early Ptolemaic period and then the Early Roman period
description: Beryl mining settlement, occupied in the Early Ptolemaic period and then the Early Roman period. The intensity of the mining activity is shown by the dozens of shafts recorded by the Delaware survey.It is located ca 3 km NNE of Sikait, the central mining settlement of the Sikait mining district.Middle Sikait is composed of three small settlements of less than a dozen huts (S, W and SW settlements), and a main settlement with four large buildings that have sometimes been identified as temples. Two phases were noted in the surface pottery found near the "temples", one dated to the Early Ptolemaic period, the other to the Roman period.See Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 145-153, for a recent description.

name: Minayh el-Hir/Aphrodites Orous
short description: Roman fort, badly damaged, in the Wadi Minayh el-Hir. Ancient Aphrodites Orous
description: Fort, badly damaged, in the Wadi Minayh el-Hir. Dated to the Roman period, it lies on the road leading from Koptos to Berenike.It is located 32.5 km to the south-east of the fort of Khashm el-Minayh/Didymoi, and 37.7 km to the north-west of Daghbag/Compasi, the two forts that are set before and after the fort of Minayh el-Hir on the Roman road.The Paneion on the wadi Minayh el-Hir is 18.4 km to the north-west, along the same road.The dedicatory inscription found at the fort allows its foundation to be dated to the reign of Vespasianus, like the forts of Iovis and Siket.The fort has never been excavated, hence the lack of data coming directly from the site, and which would allow a better understanding of its chronology, and evolution. It is likely that the fort was abandoned at the same time as the other forts of the roads were left by the Roman army, during the 3rd c. AD.The fort of the wadi Minay el-Hir is often identified with the ancient Aphrodites Orous (station of "Aphrodite of the desert"), mentioned by the Itinerarium Antoninin, the Tabula Peutingeriana, and the Cosmographia of the Anonynus of Ravenna. The toponym is also mentioned in 6 ostraca found at Didymoi, and one in Xeron Pelagos (see Cuvigny 2018&, ¬ß 125).

name: Mons Claudianus
short description: Major Roman quarry of the Eastern desert
description: Along with Berenike, Mons Claudianus is definitely the most famous site of the Eastern Desert of Egypt.Its existence is due to the presence of an ancient quarry, located ca 140km east of Qena (anc. Kaine), where grey granite was extracted. The site was discovered by Brocchi, Burton and Wilkinson in 1823. Since then, it has been visited and described by several scholars, who were more interested in the Greek and Latin inscriptions than by the settlement itself. In the 1960s, the German Institute worked there and produced a very accurate plan of the site. Finally Mons Claudianus was thoroughly excavated by an international team led by J. Bingen from 1987 to 1993.The first occupation of the site dates from the Early Empire and probably took place in what is called "The Hydreuma" (see SIT1995); the site was already named Claudianus (from the Emperor of the same name), and columns extracted from the site are known of, for example, in the domus Flavia in Rome. After a probable rebirth of the site, under the reign of Domitian (a broken inscription bearing the name of the emperor was found in situ, see Bingen 2013, p. 4), and the discovery of new quarries, with greater extraction possibilities, the site was moved slightly to the east, closer to the new quarries. It comprises, besides the quarries themselves, a large Roman fort, animal lines, a thesauros ("treasure", i.e. a granary), a temple, and a luxurious residence equipped with baths.The temple was dedicated in 118, under Hadrian's reign, while the architektones Apollonios and Herakleides left several inscriptions dated to 108-109, under Trajan. The reign of these two emperors were the floruit of the quarries' exploitation, and of the site's occupation. Several buildings in Rome, are adorned with columns that originated from the site, including Hadrian's villa.The excavations show that by then the site was exploited intermittently (Mons Claudianus granite was used in the Caracalla baths in Roma, dated to the 3rd c. AD), and visited, if not occupied, until the 4th c. AD.During the work in the Trajanic forum (early 2nd c. AD), about 1000 men worked in the quarries and 300 men are recorded in the middle of the 2nd c. AD (see O.Claud. IV, Appendix 2 and the publication of a list for the distribution of water, describing the people living and working on the site in Cuvigny 2005b).For a thorough description of the quarrying settlement, see the two monographs Peacock, Maxfield 1997, and Maxfield, Peacock 2011, the four books dedicated to the publication of the ostraca (O.Claud. I to IV), as well as the general but excellent overview Bingen 2013.

name: Nakheil
short description: Roman fort
description: Roman fort located 13km west of Myos Hormos/Quseir el-Qadim. It is not on the road leading to Koptos but on the road leading to the mines of Semna.Water is plentiful in the area and easily reachable (1m below the surface), as shown by several modern wells. Murray 1925, p. 149 mentions a pool cut in the wadi bed that served as a well. The water was salty but drinkable.The surface material dates from the late 1st/early 2nd century until the end of the Roman period. No Byzantine material was recorded by the MAFDO (Brun, Redd√©, 2003).Two other features: a necropolis and a worker village, maybe dated to the New Kingdom.

description: Isolated site at the end of wadi Naqqat, where many rock drawings (probably Prehistoric) are recorded.It comprises a well preserved building and some huts. It is probably a Christian laura.Ciglinecki 2017: "The central building of the laura Wadi Naqqat was first discovered in 1823 by Sir John Gardner Wilkinson during his trip through the Eastern desert (Wilkinson 1832: 49). Nearby, Wilkinson found a Greek inscription that clearly identified the building as a church and enabled its approximate dating to 339 AD at the latest. The church and the surrounding laura, consisting of about a dozen built hermitages, rock shelters and other minor structures, might thus well be the oldest known monastic settlement in the Eastern Desert".See also this publication for several photos of the site.

name: Philoteras
short description: Red Sea port, not precisely located
description: A Red Sea port that has not been precisely located. The site is mentioned by several ancient sources and, according to Strabo, it was founded by Satyros on his way to the Trogodytic country in search of elephants (16.4.5). A Satyros is known at Kana√Øs, where he left an inscription dated to the reign of Ptolemy II (I.Paneion 9).The town may be mentioned in the Pithom stela (but Thiers 2001, p. 7 does not mention it).The name of Philotera comes from the sister of Ptolemy II. According to Pliny (NH 6.168), it was also called Aenum.The exact location of the harbour is not known. If one follows the coordinates given by Claudius Ptolemy (although, of course, these cannot be considered to be completely accurate), it is to be found near modern Safaga. Murray 1925, p. 142 proposed, very cautiously, to locate it near the Safaga station, although he did not find any anchorage at this site. He prefers a location at the mouth of the Wadi Gawasis, although he found no remains nor available water there. The creator of the 1:250000 Map, as well as the Tabula Imperii Romani, locate the site accordingly, more precisely, at the place named Marsa Gawasis. Since then it has been proved that the site hosted a Middle Kingdom harbour (see SIT1779 and the Italian Archaeological Expedition at Mersa/Wadi Gawasis).Interesting enough, Tregenza found some Greek fragments in 1951, which led Meredith 1952, p. 105 to conclude that the hypothesis to locate Philotera at Marsa Gawasis was right. This is still the hypothesis of Van Rengen 2001, p. 233-236 for example.Would it be possible that the Pharaonic site was reused by the Ptolemies? It looks like there was a Middle Kingdom occupation at Berenike, so this is likely to have also occurred at other harbours, all the more so that good anchorages are not so numerous on the Red Sea shore.However, no evidence was found during the Italian Archaeological Expedition's excavations at Mersa/Wadi Gawasis and it is thus impossible to precisely locate the harbour (see Van Rengen 2018 for the most recent discussions, in particular p. 12-16).

name: Porphyrites, Footpath station

description: Small fort on the southern flank of the Gebel Dokhan, on the zigzag pathway leading from the main settlement of the Porphyrites to Badia.Its purpose was probably to guard the pass.The pathway was accessible to camels, but wagons could not follow it and had to go further west to gain access to the main site of the Porphyrites.

name: Porphyrites, Lykabettus Village
short description: Quarry and village of the Porphyrites district occupied in the Late Roman period
description: "Lykabettus Village is the most spectacularly situated of all the quarry villages" of the Porphyrites district (Maxfield, Peacock 2001b, p. 111).It lies about 1200 m high, to the east of the quarry sites on the mountain top.It is accessed by a steep slipway and is organised according to the natural settings of the site, with no flat ground available.The village comprises 64 rooms, organised in five blocks. The quarries are located to the west, on the peak of one of the highest moutains of the Porphyrites.The occupation of the quarries and village is Late Roman in date, mainly during the fourth c. AD.See Maxfield, Peacock 2001b, p. 110-129, 172-190 for a thorough description of the village and quarries.

description: Quarry and workers' village in the Porphyrites district that was first visited by Burton and Wilkinson in 1823.The site is located near the quarries it served. The village is accessible from the fort of the wadi Maamal, and from the quarries of the Lykabettus, by foot. The main approach is from the north-east, through a wadi leading to the wadi Maamal.The village comprises five "blocks" of buildings, all well preserved, three to the west part of a ravine, and two to the east. The quarries are impressive, and equipped with a network of roads, paths and slipways, and have been heavily exploited.The site was probably built in the mid-1st c. AD, and abandoned in the middle of the next century. The quarries may have been re-exploited at the end of their exploitation period, in the Late Roman period.The village and the quarries are very thoroughly described, and illustrated, in Maxfield, Peacock 2001b (with a beautiful reconstitution of the village p. 85).

name: Porphyrites, Southwest village
short description: Quarry and workers' village of the Porphyrites district
description: The Southwest Village was not been seen by many travelers before the work done in the 1990s in the whole of the Porphyrites area.The first plan was drawn by Kraus et al. 1967, and the only thorough study of the village was published by Maxfield, Peacock 2001b, p. 86-104. No excavations took place, but a systematic survey was done.This is explained by the fact that the village is not easily seen from the other settlements in the area. It is located on low ground, below and separated from the quarries that it served. It is situated in the wadi bed towards the head of the wadi Abu Maamel, 3 km south of the main fort. It is accessed by a built road that is still well preserved.The village comprises three raised sites on which buildings are constructed: areas A, B and C. In total, more than a hundred rooms are recorded.The village is functionally linked by roads to the Rammius quarries (which are only accessable from here) and the Lykabettus quarries (which was also served by another hill-top village). The material points to an early occupation (late first to mid-second c. AD), while the Lykabettus quarries were still in use during the Late Roman period.The excavators think that the southwest village had "a significant role in the early period but thereafter has occupied a secondary position - abandoned, perhaps, for a while, and briefly reoccupied to service the large-scale-fourth-century exploitation on Lykabettus" (Maxfield, Peacock 2001b, p. 104).

name: Porphyrites, The Bradford Village
short description: Quarry and small village, possible first settlement of the Porphyrites district
description: Small quarrying village discovered in 1995. It comprises seven huts, is situated high in the mountains on a steep slope, between two slipways leading to the northern and southern quarries.Many of the huts contained pottery, sometimes near-complete vessels.The occupational evidence, taken in conjonction with the limited extent of quarrying, points to a single, short period of use.A stele was found inside the hut 1, in front of the niche in its eastern wall. In the center is a depiction of Pan-Min, on his left is an incense-burner, and on the right is a Greek inscription that identifies the building with a Paneion. Above all, the text provides a date (23 July AD 18) which probably marks the foundation of the building but also of the quarry complex.The quarries lay to the north-east and to the west of the village. Black porphyry was extracted, probably for a very short span of time.

name: Porphyrites, The Foot Village
short description: Quarry and small village of the Porphyrites district, possibly of Tiberian date
description: Quarry and small village in the Porphyrites district located at the foot of the mountain slope, at the head of an unnamed wadi which also contained the North-West Village (see SIT0153).The village may have welcomed a sanctuary. A Tiberian inscription, found in the torrent bed has been assumed to derive from the North-West village, but the pottery of the Foot Village is similar to that of the Bradford Village, which is a Tiberian foundation. It is thus highly plausible that the inscription comes from the Foot Village, which owes its name to the discovery of a stone cut in the shape of a foot near a large building.

name: Porphyrites, Wadi Maamal
short description: Main settlement of the major metallon (quarry) where porphyry was extracted during the Roman period
description: Main settlement of the major metallon (quarry) where porphyry was extracted during the Roman period.The site is located to the north of the Eastern Desert, not far from the coastal plain bordering the Red Sea. It "was not easy of access, being approached only via torturous, boulder-strewn wadis" (Maxfield, Peacock 2001, p. X).The main settlement lay towards the southern end of the wadi Abu Maamel, at the heart of the quarrying district that extends to the north, north-west, south-west and east (see the other sites of the district, such as the Lykabettus Village, the Foot Village, the North-West Village, the South-West Village and the Bradford Village). The settlement comprises a fortified settlement ('fort'), an isolated building to the south (maybe a bath building), a small settlement for quarry workers, a necropolis, 2 and maybe 3 temples, and wells.The main period of activity in the fort and the adjacent buildings, as well as in the nearby quarries is dated to the Antonine period (the occupation of the district, in the Bradford and Northwest Village was earlier, starting under Tiberius). The fort was maybe shortly reoccupied, and the nearby quarries re-exploited, in the late 2nd-early 3rd c. AD, and the site was then abandoned.From then on, the military ocupation of the district was maybe transfered to Badia, where it lasted until the late 4th or 5th c. AD. Other quarries were activated or re-activated in the 4th c. AD, like the Lykabettus quarries, and the final abandonment of the district was situated in the first half of the 5th c. AD. The main settlement and the majority of the other sites of the district were rediscovered in 1822 by James Burton.

name: Qalt el-Naqah
short description: Ptolemaic gold mining settlement
description: Mining settlement found by S. Sidebotham and his team, not registered by the Klemms.It comprises a building with ca 17 rooms, built in stone. It measures ca 17 x 16.4m, and its S side may have been destroyed by a flood.Grinding stones were recorded by the survey, indicating that the site may have served as a mining settlement, probably during the Ptolemaic period, which is the main period of gold exploitation in the Eastern Desert. This is verified by the presence of Ptolemaic pottery on the site (Sidebotham 1996a, p. 185). Early Roman pottery is also recorded but this could just indicate that the site was still visited in that period.According to our network reconstruction, the Delaware team's Bedouin guide and the MAFDO survey conducted in 2020, the site of Qalt el-Naqah was accessible from the Ptolemaic mining settlement of Ghozza. The south gold mines of Ghozza are located less than 4km from Qalt el-Naqah.To the NW and up to the south mines of Ghozza, many works, that cannot be modern from their shape and size, are probable ancient mining works. It probably indicates that the district of Ghozza was heavily worked in Antiquity, and that Qalt el-Naqah is a satellite settlement that served to host a part of the workers that worked in the area.A small rectangular building, that could be ancient, is also visible on satellite views.

name: Qasr Hadie
short description: Large tower, near Myos Hormos, not dated
description: Large tower, near Myos Hormos. It is not dated, but probably Roman, like the majority of the towers in the region.

name: Qattar
short description: Roman fort, with animal lines
description: Roman fort, with animal lines. Occupied in the Early Roman period and in the 3rd-4th c. AD.The fort is rectangular in shape, measuring 44 x 36m. The main gate is on the west, flanked by semicircular towers. The fort also has circular towers at each corner. According to Wilkinson, the enclosure was preserved enough that he could see a parapet and a catwalk.The interior rooms are arranged along the curtain wall, to the N and E. To the W, the rooms seem larger and are built inside the courtyard of the fort. Two modern wells were dug inside the fort in modern times. One of them bears an inscription dated to the reign of Prince Farouk (1920-1937), according to the Delaware survey. A tower built outside the fort may be contemporaneous with the modern wells.One of the wells, seen by Murray (who said it was dry) was apparently reused by one of the two modern wells (Scaife 1935, p. 77).One or several floods destroyed the SW part of the fort. Also the interior was damaged between Murray's and Scaife's visits, in the 1920s or early 1930s.It is located 21km (by foot) from Deir el-Atrash and the path is materialised by cairns on the SE side of the wadi el-Atrash according to Scaife 1935.

name: Qaw el-Kebir/Antaeopolis
short description: City in the Nile Valley, ancient Tjebu and Antaeopolis.
description: City in the Nile Valley, ancient Tjebu and Antaeopolis.The site is included here because the city may have had relationships with sites in the Eastern Desert.Qaw el-Kebir was the capital of the tenth Upper Egyptian nome.

name: Qena/Kaine

name: Qirayyah
short description: Important Roman station on the road to the Mons Claudianus and the gold mines of the central Eastern desert
description: Important Roman station on the road to the Mons Claudianus and the gold mines of the central Eastern Desert.It comprises three buildings: a small fort with a well, that was 17m deep at the time of Murray's visit (Murray 1925, p. 148), nearby animal lines, and a square building, located 430m to the west of the animal lines, that has now been almost entirely destroyed by the construction of a modern railway.The two enclosures were connected by a canalization that was seen by Wilkinson and Barron and Hume.According to Meredith 1952, p. 102, the presence of animal lines and mudbricks is an indication that it was part of the "quarry road", leading to the Porphyrites and Mons Claudianus, and not to the sea road leading to Abu Shaar.

name: Quei
short description: Roman (?) fort, that has now totally vanished
description: Roman (?) fort, that has now totally vanished. It was discovered by Murray in 1922 (Murray 1925, p. 149), but it had already been badly destroyed (only a corner of the station remained). In 1992, S. Sidebotham visited the site but was not able to locate the fort (he noted only a few sherds on the surface).

name: Quft/Coptos
short description: City in the Nile Valley, ancient Gebtu and Coptos.
description: City in the Nile Valley, ancient Gebtu and Coptos.The site is included here because the city had relationships with sites in the Eastern Desert. Expeditions were sent from this city to the desert, in particular to the wadi Hammamat, and to the Red Sea.It was the capital of the fifth Upper Egyptian nome.Presentation on the IFAO website, by Laure Pantalacci:https://www.ifao.egnet.net/recherche/archeologie/coptos/

name: Quseir el-Qadim/Myos Hormos
short description: Major harbour on the Red Sea, in the Ptolemaic and Roman period, end of one road coming from Coptos
description: The ancient site of Quseir el-Qadim is 8 km to the north of the modern city of Quseir, at the head of a bay and behind a silted coral lagoon that was suitable for naval utilisation (Whitcomb, Johnson 1979, p. 1).It is at the end of the wadi Hammamat, the shortest road that links the Nile Valley (from Quft) to the Red Sea, and thus a major harbour on the Red Sea coast.The site is approximately 10 ha in area, located on a terrace overlooking the entrance to the bay from the lagoon. A limited surface has been excavated recently, in the 1970s by the Oriental Institute of Chicago and 2000s by the University of Southampton. Both works proved that the assumption that the site should be identified as Myos Hormos was correct. Indeed for almost a century, the site was wrongly located at Abu Shaar (see SIT0026) which proved to be a Late Roman fort. For Couyat, in 1910, Quseir el-Qadim was an "Arab port" (1910b, p. 526), an opinion followed by many scholars after him. Even the Chicago mission was not keen to identify the site with Myos Hormos and proposed an identification with Leukos Limen (see Bargnall 1986). The discovery of eight ostraca by the MAFDO at El-Zarqa/Maximianon gave the definitive argument for the identification (B√ºlow-Jacobsen, Cuvigny, Fournet 1994, with some previous arguments given by Peacock 1993b), together with ostraca and papyrus found at Quseir el-Qadim afterwards (Peacock et al. 2000, p. 51).The remains excavated by the two missions date mainly to the Roman period, and to the Ayyubid and Mamluk era.However, even if the Ptolemaic remains found on the site are scarce (some fragments of glass, coins of Ptolemy III and VI, and Cleopatra VII, and Ptolemaic pottery, see Van Rengen 2018, p. 5), "Myos Hormos is undoubtedly a Ptolemaic foundation, because the port is mentioned by Agatharchides of Knidos (second half of the second century BC)." (Van Rengen 2018, p. 2). "The port enjoyed substantial growth during the Augustan era: 120 ships left each year for India and Arabia (Strabo 2, 5, 12)." (idem) and indeed the first traces of occupation date back to the late 1st c. BC and with particular intensity in the 1st c. AD. Then the site was abandoned in the mid-3rd c. AD, and reused as a harbour in the 12th-15th c. AD. The Islamic occupation was not as large as the Roman one and even if the ancient site has suffered from the proximity of the sea and the reoccupation, the remains are preserved well enough to reconstruct the history of the city, if not its layout (the excavations were too limited to do so).It showed that the lagoon was used as an inner bay and linked to the sea through a channel. The waterfront was set out with dozens of amphorae (Dressel 2-4 dated to the 1st c. BC/1st c. AD, see Blue 2009, p. 271-274) set vertically in the silt and covered with earth, as well as stone-built jetties. Several buildings were excavated in the town itself, in particular a significant building in the centre of the town, maybe a temple, a "Roman villa", in the NW part of the town, but also more common houses (see Whitcomb, Johnson 1979 and 1982a). The materiel is abundant and proves the insertion of the harbour in the Red Sea networks (and beyond). Besides, the numerous Ô¨Ånds related to shipbuilding activities, and Ô¨Åshing also show the dynamism of the city as a harbour (Thomas 2012, Blue 2009).In his journal (De Castro 1541), Joan de Castro  wrote that "in old times, the town of Kossir was built two leagues farther up the coast; but being found incommodious, especially as the harbour at that place was too small, it was removed to this place (Quseir)." It confirms that Quseir el-Qadim was already abandoned during the 16th century after its medieval reoccupation.

name: Rod el-Buram
short description: Ptolemaic station on the road Edfu-Marsa Nakari
description: Small station discovered by the University of Delaware in 1995, on the road from Edfu to Marsa Nakari.It is composed of 20-24 huts and a tank.The surface pottery is Ptolemaic according to the Delaware survey, which visited the site on 4 occasions.Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 240 ask whether the site could also have been in use in the Roman period, since it has a perfect location on the Roman road from Koptos to Berenike, between the fort of Dios/Abu Qurayyah and the fort of Xeron Pelagos. name: Rod el-Gamra
short description: Early Ptolemaic quarry (dolerite) porphyry and associated workers' village
description: The quarrying site of Rod el-Gamra is located in a vast plain to the south-east of Bir Samut, and the Ptolemaic road leading from Edfu to Berenike.It comprises a dolerite porphyry quarry and an associated workers' village composed of five or six huts. Five naoi are still in situ.The dating of the site is based on the surface pottery diagnosis made by the Delaware survey in 2003, which recorded pottery from the late fourth to mid-second century BC. Previously, the site was dated to the Late Period as well, but no sherds from that period were found during the survey.This is one of the earliest  known quarries in the Eastern Desert for the post-Pharaonic period. The limited size of the settlement show that the exploitation was short and/or seasonal.

name: Rod el-Logah
short description: Small Ptolemaic station
description: Small Ptolemaic station on the road from Edfu to Berenike. It is 14 km east of Abu Garaish (a satellite of Bir Samut and possible stop on the road) and almost 24 km from Bir Samut, a large fort that had a crucial role in the logistics of the road. To the east, it is 21 km from Seyhrig, the next station on the road.The site is on a small eminence at the edge of the wadi and sheltered by a small hill to the north, which protects it from winds and floods.The pottery at the surface dates from the Ptolemaic period. The site has never been excavated but it is probable that excavations would show that the station was founded when the road system was set up at the end of Ptolemy II's reign.

name: Rod Umm el-Farag
short description: Ptolemaic and Early Roman station on the road from Edfu to Marsa Nakari
description: Site located on the road leading from Edfu to Marsa Nachari, between Sheikh Salem and Rod el-Buram.It is considered as a road station by Sidebotham 2011b, p. 132, equipped with animal lines.On the satellite images, a circular enclosure is very visible, with a possible well at the center. The enclosure measures 26.5 (E/W) x 20m (N/S). The animal lines mentioned by Sidebotham are not visible.The surface pottery is Ptolemaic and Early Roman according to R.S. Tomber (Sidebotham 1999, p. 367).

name: Safaga station
short description: Small station, probably Roman, on the Via Hadriana (but the fort is poorly dated)
description: Small station, probably Roman, on the Via Hadriana (but the fort is poorly dated). Could also be a station on the road from Qena to a port on the Red Sea located near Safaga. Couyat wrongly suggested locating the harbour of Myos Hormos nearby. Located in the center of the wadi Safaga, the station stands only 130m from a modern road. It probably opened onto the west side, as shown by an interruption in its enclosure.The enclosure is square in shape and its sides are 31-32m in length. Its SW and SE corners are destroyed.According to Sidebotham, Hense, Nouwens 2008, p. 52, remains of a cistern and several rooms are visible. No traces of an internal well, but the center of the enclosure has been washed away. On the satellite images, trees are visible inside the fort, probably at the ancient location of the well.

name: Samut el-Beda
short description: Large New Kingdom gold settlement
description: Large New Kingdom gold settlement of 216 huts. It was prospected by the MAFDO in 2015, and a few huts were excavated in 2016.

name: Semna
short description: Ptolemaic gold mining site, with Roman reoccupation (?)
description: Ptolemaic gold mining site, located near the railway track and a railway bridge, in the wadi Semna.The site comprises mining facilities including a quadrangular structure identified as a "processing plant" by R. and D. Klemm, a large enclosure  which is more likely a protected well, two workers' villages, and vein works, all spread over an area of 800 m north-south and 500 m east-west.The site was occupied during the Ptolemaic period, as shown by the grinding mills, two ostraca found during the MAFDO survey of 2019, and the diagnostic of the pottery by Jennifer Gates-Foster.Eight fragments of possibly seven Latin inscriptions, one mentioning the prefect of Egypt and a high-ranking official in the Eastern Desert in the 150s, were found by Tregenza in 1950 and 1951 in the wadi, near the mining settlement (on the contrary to what has been said by others about  Tregenza's finds, Tregenza is very clear about the location of these spot finds). This could indicate a Roman presence at the site, unless the inscriptions come from Deir el-Wikalah, the neighbour Roman station.

name: Semna mine
short description: New Kingdom, Ptolemaic and possibly older gold mining site
description: New Kingdom, Ptolemaic and possibly older mining site located in a secondary (unnamed) wadi in the NNO-SSE direction, leading to the wadi Umm Garahish al-Bahari (which itself joins the wadi Semna near the archaeological site of Deir el-Wikalah). The site is 3.4 km south of the Ptolemaic gold mining site of Semna.The site of the Semna mine is entirely dedicated to the exploitation of gold. Among the remains are several quartz veins of New Kingdom and Ptolemaic date, as well as a New Kingdom settlement (cluster of huts), and a Ptolemaic levee, which is probably a protected well.More recently it was operated by two British mining companies, Eridia Exploration Company Limited and Fatira Exploring Company Limited between 1904 and 1906. There was also work in the 1950s carried out by a subcontractor of the Egyptian Phosphate Company. Eridia Exploration Company Limited was registered in 1903 and dismantled in 1906 along with the other company. An English mining journal of 1905 reported that some pillars in the old work areas contained up to 5.5 ounces of gold per ton.

name: Seyhrig
short description: Ptolemaic small station with Late period occupation and Roman reoccupation
description: Small station with two circular tanks, discovered by the Delaware team.It is located on the Ptolemaic road from Edfu to Berenike, 21 km east of Rod el-Logah and 25 km west of Umm Maryah/Umm Shera/Umm Qaria.Seyhrig is 12 km to the NE of Dweig/Phalakro and thus off the Roman road from Koptos to Berenike. This explains why there is no post-Vespasianic occupation of the site.Late Period material was found on the surface by the Delaware survey, this is one of the only sites where such pottery has been recovered so far (Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 177).The main building found at Seyhrig is very similar to other Ptolemaic stations on the Edfu-Berenike road, like Abu Rahal East or Rod el-Logah. The station was probably part of the large building program under Ptolemy II, to organize travel along the road from Edfu to Berenike. The surface pottery shows that it was still visited until the Late Ptolemaic and Early Roman period.No well was recorded in the vicinity and the only water structures that were seen during the Delaware and MAFDO surveys were the two circular tanks, another common feature of the Ptolemaic road (see Abu Midrik for example).A skopelos is located on the top of the adjacent hill. Cairns were seen by the Delaware survey on the top of adjacent hills. No well was seen.Based on Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 177-180.

name: Shealeq
short description: Graves and cairns, and a possible well protected by an enclosure
description: Graves and cairns, and a possible well protected by an enclosure (but it could also be modern).Could be a stop on the road coming from Berenike (south), at the intersection with the road coming from Lahmi to the west.

name: Shenshef
short description: Important Late Roman and possibly Early Roman settlement in the area south of Berenike, with a hill-top fort and more than 300 buildings
description: Important settlement in the area south of Berenike, approximately one days walk from the city (21km as the crow flies). It comprises a hill-top fort on the east side of the site, as well as more than 300 buildings spread over a distance of 800m on both sides of the wadi. Some of them, in the south part, are very well-built and exceptionally well-preserved, up to 3m high. These buildings have their lintels, windows and niches preserved. Some of them have courtyards.To the north of the settlement, the buildings are much simpler huts. Besides this, hundreds of tombs have been recorded near the lower settlement (see Barnard 1998).Eight trenches were opened by the Berenike project in 1997.The pottery found in the village by the Berenike Project is dated to the Late Roman period (5th-early 6th c. AD). In the fort, the pottery dates to the late 1st c. BC/early 1st c. AD (Cappers 2006, p. 18).Surface water is present in abundance according to Cappers 2006, p. 18-19 (see fig. 1.7) and Aldsworth 1999, thanks to the narrowing of the wadi and the shallow sand layer, which would allow agriculture.The function of the settlement is unknown. The difference in chronology between the fort and the settlement raises many unsolved questions (see Jackson 2002, p. 92).It should be concluded that the fort was built at the same time as the large fort of Kalalat and the fort of Siket, and then abandoned at the same time as the large fort of Kalalat. Its purpose was to protect the city and maybe the trade roads leading to it.Then the site was abandoned and only re-occupied in the Late Roman period, which was the apex of the occupation of Berenike. During that period, the function of the settlement is unknown, although it should be stressed that its location recalls the location of Karim, in the hinterland of Myos Hormos, which was maybe dedicated to supplying water to the harbour. The variety of artefacts found during the excavations (in particular saphir from Sri Lanka, pepper from India, the many seeds and vegetables studied by Cappers 2006, as well as teak, beads, sorghum from India, olives, almonds, umbrella pines from the Mediterranaen) indicate that the population of Shenshef was wealthy (see for a summary Sidebotham 2011a, p. 275-276).

name: Sigdit

description: Roman road station according to Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 159-160 or Christian community village, according to Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 261 (the Delaware survey records only 4th to 6th c. The village could have been a Christian community similar to the villages of Heran, Nugrus west and Bir Minayh  (Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 261-262).Near the Bir Sigdit, Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 262 and Rothe, Miller, Rapp 2008, p. 234-238 have recorded Pharaonic inscriptions. They do not mention dates, but the titles correspond to those of Old Kingdom expeditions (see Eichler 1993).

It is the largest beryl mining settlement of the whole Eastern Desert and the surveys and excavations of the Delaware mission yielded a significant amount of material and information about the site.

name: Siket
short description: Fort and watering place to supply Berenike with water, located 7km W/WN of the city
description: Fort and watering place to supply Berenike with water, located 7km W/WN of the city, and 1km from the road leading from Berenike to Edfu and Koptos, via Abu Qurayyah.The fort measures 24 x 32 to 38m, and comprises 4 oval-shaped towers, one at each corner, and two semi-circular towers on each side of the gate. The gate opens onto the north. A second door is visible to the south, and was blocked at some point.A trench was opened by the Berenike project in the gate where two monolithic doorjambs and a triangular-shaped inscription were found. The inscription is written in Latin and bears the dedicatory inscription of the fort. It mentions the founding of a hydreuma, praesidium and lacus in 76/77 AD. Similar inscriptions have been found at Menih el-Hir/Aphrodites Orous, and Khashm el-Menih/Didymoi.In the center of the enclosure, a vast depression probably hosted the well, but it has never been seen by modern travalers or archaeologists.Two accumulations of debris are located against the west wall (with an interruption, which probably means that a postern is located here) and the east wall. They are probably the result of well dredging but could also be dumps, in particular the west one.(From Pintozzi 2007).

name: Sodmein
short description: Ptolemaic and New Kingdom settlement, but this is not certain
description: The site has only been viewed on satellite pictures by D. and R. Klemm: "To judge by the location and arrangement of the houses, the main settlement located in a side wadi seems to belong to the New Kingdom category based on wadiworkings. A smaller settlement (partially washed away) surrounded by a heavy, rectangular wall in the main wadi probably dates to the Ptolemaic Period." (Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 132)This site must not be mistaken for the prehistorical site of Sodmein Cave, 9 km to the northeast.

name: Sukkari
short description: Gold mining site with settlements from the New Kingdom and the Ptolemaic Period, with a Roman and Late Roman reoccupation
description: Gold mining site with settlements dated to the New Kingdom and the Ptolemaic Period, with a Roman and Late Roman reoccupation.The ancient remains have suffered greatly from a modern reoccupation in the early 20th century, and a present-day reoccupation, that is even more destructive.

name: Tadnos Fons
short description: "Spring of Tadnos" near Myos Hormos
description: "Spring of Tadnos" (the spelling "Ainos" has been challenged by several scholars, like J. Desanges in his French edition of Pliny‚Äôs Natural History, who prefered the spelling Tadnos) mentioned by Pliny near Myos Hormos (NH 6.26.103c).When Myos Hormos was located by scholars at Abu Shaar (see SIT0026), Tadnos Fons was supposed to be Abu Shaar el-Qibli (SIT0028), and thus is represented in many ancient maps at this location.The site of Myos Hormos has now been identified with Quseir el-Qadim and the spring of Tadnos, which should be in the vicinity, has not yet been located, although Cr√©py and Redon recently proposed locating the site at Ayn el-Ghazal (or Bir Ambagi, DN_SIT0248), a famous watering place where large quantities of water are available (Cr√©py, Redon forthcoming). The site has been lengthily described by several modern travelers. Indeed, the area is well documented because it is located on an important crossing point where at least four roads connecting the Nile valley to the Red Sea meet between Bir Beida/Bir al-Ingliz and the port of Quseir. It is located 7 km south-west of Quseir al-Qadim/Myos Hormos, and results from a local hydrogeological configuration which make this spring perennial on an historical scale. The source was particularly striking to travelers, as it gives birth to extensive wetlands, that are almost unique in the Eastern Desert. The water quality was judged as bad by most of the travelers, but they did not drink the water from the spring directly, but instead from the swamps.

name: Tell el-Amarna
short description: City in the Valley, ancient Akhetaten.
description: Ancient Akhetaten.The site is located in the Nile valley and is not part of the sites studied and described by the project. It is included here because the city may have had relationships with sites in the Eastern Desert.It was the capital of Egypt during a short period of the reign of Akhenaten, during the New Kingdom.

name: The Hydreuma
short description: Small fort near the Mons Claudianus main site, 1 km to the SW of the Mons Claudianus main fort.
description: Small fort near the Mons Claudianus main site, 1 km to the SW of the Mons Claudianus main fort.The name was given by Schweinfurth, due to the presence of several tanks inside the enclosure (although there is no well, which is, normally, the condition of the denomination "hydreuma").The site has been known for a long-time by the travellers who visited the Mons Claudianus. It was studied by the German mission in the 1960s and again by Peacock in 1992, who drew the first plan after Wilkinson. It has never been excavated, except in 1993, when four small trenches were dug in the trash dump and in the village by J.-M. Carri√©, with H. Cuvigny (Carri√© 2001).The site comprises a small fort occupying a dominant position on a rocky promontory, irregularly organised buildings at the foot of the fort that could be the remnants of a workers' village, and finally a large building built on a terrace, identified by Lepsius as the commandant's house.The pottery is mainly Trajanic, as well as the ostraca, like the Mons Claudianus. But one trash dump associated with the village yielded an ostracon dated to the reign of Nero (AD 68, MC inv. H44) on one layer dated to the second phase of the occupation. The site is thus likely to be more ancient than the Mons Claudianus main site, maybe a first attempt that was later supplemented by the larger fort (Peacock 1997c, p. 148). This could explain the name of the quarry, which refers to the Emperor Claudianus (Carri√© 2001, p. 166). Indeed the ostraca also show that the site was called Mons Claudianus.The reconstruction of the southern part of the village may date to the reign of Trajan and could be named Fons Traianus Dacicus, according to Carri√© 2001, p. 166-167.(based on Peacock 1997c and Carri√© 2001).

name: Thinis

description: City in the Nile Valley.The site is included here because the city may have had relationships with sites in the Eastern Desert. It was the capital of the eighth Upper Egyptian nome.The exact location of the site is not sure, but it was probably in the region of modern Girga.

short description: City in the Nile Valley, ancient Djerty and Tuphium.

name: Tum
short description: Small site discovered by the University of Delaware, between Shenshef and Hitan Rayan
description: Small site discovered by the University of Delaware, between Shenshef and Hitan Rayan.The site is composed of two buildings that, according to the archaeologists, are well built, on the north slope of the Wadi Tum.The surface pottery is Late Roman but some possible Early Roman surface pottery has also been noticed.The function of this settlement is unknown, although its position part way between Shenshef and Hitan Rayan suggests that it could have been a stop between the two sites, according to Sidebotham 1999, p. 361. However, the site is not located on the easiest and fastest way between the two sites, and it is a little off-road, in a secondary wadi. It appears more likely that it was a stop on the road coming from the coast and leading to Hitan Rayan.

name: Umm Arbain
short description: Possible New Kingdom settlements, but they are poorly dated
description: Possible New Kingdom settlements, but they are poorly dated (Klemm, Klemm 2013, p. 212, under the name "Wadi Faraon").The University of Delaware visited the site in 1997. They saw a small settlement, possibly of the Late Roman period, and an Early Medieval cemetery (Sidebotham 1999, p. 366-367, Sidebotham 2011b, p. 132). The site is a station according to Pleiades but this is doubtful, taking into account that this is not stated in the Barrington Atlas, nor in Sidebotham 1999.

name: Umm Balad
short description: Roman fort and quarries
description: Umm Balad is 5km from Badia, and hosts one of the best-preserved forts of the northern part of the desert (up to 6m high), according to Scaife.It is located near two diorite quarries, the stones of which were used in Rome from the reign of Domitian (Gnoli 1971, p. 133). But the site was soon abandoned probably due to the quite poor quality of the stone. The site (more precisely the metallon, i.e. the quarry) is called Domitiane and Kaine Latomia in the ostraca. From the presence of quarry marks similar to those found at the Prophyrites, it is likely that Umm Balad was part of the same administrative unit as the nearby Porphyrites (B√ºlow-Jacobsen 2018, ¬ß 9).The fort is rectangular in shape and measures 49 x 38m. Its main gate is to the east and is flanked by semi-circular towers, and protected by a clavicula, like in Badia.Inside the enclosure are several rooms (organised along the curtain wall) and other rooms organised in blocks on both sides of the streets. A tank is located at the end of the main street, in front of the entrance. Unlike the fort of the Myos Hormos and Berenike road, there is no space inside the fort for a large well (as there is in Badia and Qattar).Apart from the fort and the quarries, a small hill sanctuary is also preserved to the north-west, as well as a forge, two outside buildings and a necropolis, located 300m to the east of the fort.There is apparently no water on the site and water was brought by camels from wells in the neighbourhood (B√ºlow-Jacobsen 2013b, p. 571).

name: Umm Dhaya
short description: Settlement/possible quarry along Via Nova Hadriana
description: A Ptolemaic settlement and possible quarry along the Via Nova Hadriana, near its intersection with the Red Sea coastal road that departs north from the site. According to Paprocki, abandoned before 30 BCE. He mentions Ptolemaic inscriptions, but it is not clear that they have been published. Listed in Sidebotham's (2011b) tables as a settlement/ possible quarry but not discussed in the text. There is a well on the site and it is also close to Qalt Gharib (SIT0438).

name: Umm Diqal
short description: Roman station located 2.9km from the Mons Claudianus, and Late Roman settlement
description: In the wadi Umm Diqal, the site appears on the NF 36 K4d map under the name of its well, Bir Umm Duqal. The site is 2.9 km (by a track) SW of Mons Claudianus (located just behind the relief to the NNE). It lies on the edge of the current El-Geesh - Hurghada road.It comprises two subsites, that may be contemporaneous, and dated to the Late Roman period: a station, and a settlement.The station encloses a very deep well, built over a great height (at least 8 to 10 m, perhaps more), corresponding to the thickness of the loose alluvial deposits of the wadi. The lower part was dug in the substrate and provides water: the well's recharge is therefore based on the deep fractured aquifer. Water was in the bottom of the well during our visit. The SW corner of the fort appears to have been disturbed by flooding.The Late Roman settlement is composed of about 300 huts, very variable in size and shape, built on both sides of the wadi Diqal, where the Late Roman well and the Umm Diqal enclosure stands, and in a tributary to the south.

name: Umm Esh el-Zarqa north
short description: New Kingdom gold settlement
description: Around this point, the wadis are covered by traces of New Kingdom gold exploitation: heaps of crushed quartz, huts and tools, according to Klemm, Klemm 2013.The quartz veins do not show traces of extraction, so it is possible that the blocks found in the bed of the wadis were sufficient for a gold exploitation during that period.Further north, a quartz vein was mined during the Old/Middle Kingdom, according to the tools found by the Klemms.

name: Umm Esh inscription
short description: Inscription of Ramses III
description: Ramses III inscription in the area of Wadi Atalla and Umm Esh el-Zarqa (the exact location is unpublished).Described by Green in Green 1909, p. 321-322, no. 40.The Klemms saw an inscription on a rock in the Wadi Atalla, shortly before the inlet to the mining district of Atalla (see the site Atalla), that they identify to the inscription described by Green. It was complete in 1989, but had been almost completely destroyed by 1995. Since their photo does not correspond to the drawings of Green, the identification of this inscription is not confirmed.In Barron, Hume 1902, miners' huts with stone tools and shalow pits are signaled, but not dated.

name: Umm Fawakhir
short description: Major gold mining settlement in the Late Roman period; Ptolemaic temple and Roman fort
description: Together with the El-Sid settlement, the Umm Fawakhir mining site is one of the most important gold mining sites of the Eastern Desert.The main feature of the Umm Fawakhir site is a miners' village of more than 200 huts. Its main period of occupation was the 5th and 6th c. AD.However, the site was occupied long before then. In particular by a Roman fort and settlement called Persou (or Persou kai Tamostymis, see below) in the ostraca, built during the first century AD. It was renown for its gardens where vegetables and herbs were grown and were sent to the other forts of the area. This peculiarity comes from the presence of high quantities of water.The fort has now totally disappeared. According to Henry Wright, it was near the modern mosque (Meyer 1994, p. 43), while A. Reinach thinks it was near the well.The ostraca O.Faw. comes "from a dozen of huts located near the mines" (Gu√©raud 1942, p. 143, 148). Apart from 3 ostraca that may be more ancient, the other ostraca found at Umm Fawakhir and published by Gu√©raud are dated to the reign of Trajan and Hadrian. However, the Roman station is more ancient, as proven by a letter sent by the curator of the praesidium to Koptos in 55 AD (O.Petrie Mus. 112), and a document found at Umm Fawakhir and dated to 40/42 AD with a clear military context (O.Faw. 14 = SB 6 9017 14).The Roman station was probably called Persou (like the small village located 5km to the west) and Tamostymis (or Persou kai Tamostymis), which could be its Ptolemaic name (see Cuvigny 2003, p. 281-282).Indeed, the existence of a settlement dated to the Ptolemaic period at the same place is probable. This is deduced from the presence of a possible temple of Min dated to the reign of Ptolemy 3, and an ostracon of the 3rd c. BC (see the subsite for more details).

name: Umm Huwaytat
short description: Gold mining settlement, mainly Ptolemaic
description: Ptolemaic gold mining village, located in the wadi Mubarak, a few meters south of Bir Umm Huwaytat. It corresponds to the Klemms' "Umm Rus Ptolemaic Settlement".The site is organized on both sides of the Wadi Mubarak with a large building and its annex to the south, which could have been an administrative building, or a working place, in view of the dozens of grinding mills found in it, and a miners' village to the north.The whole settlement is linked to gold exploitation, and is mainly Ptolemaic. There is no evidence that the site was in use when the Via Hadriana - which could have run nearby - was opened. A New Kingdom occupation is possible, to the south of the southern building.A well (Bir Umm Huwaytat), likely modern, is still visible at the intersection between the W and E parts of this northern site.

name: Umm Huyut
short description: Quarrying settlement near the road from Mons Claudianus to Qena
description: Quarrying settlement (tonalite gneiss) near the road from Mons Claudianus to Qena. The stone from this quarry, (virtually identical to that quarried at Mons Claudianus) has been identified in Rome (for example in the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore).Associated with the four small quarries is a small settlement of 14 buildings in dry laid stone, including a larger building, maybe of administrative or cultic purpose. It is carefully built and built on a small artificial hill, higher than the other buildings. It is ca 9.3 x 7.3m, and is accessed via two staircases. Inside the building, composed of only one room, is a bench on the SW, W and NW sides. A square apse is built in front of the entrance.25m to the NW, is another notable building, of ca 34.9 x 8.3m, with 11 rooms, organised in 3 rows of rooms forming a T with a small axis. The other buildings have 1, 2, 3 and even 4 rooms and are built on the fringe of the wadi. Some of them have courtyards.(See Sidebotham 1996a, p. 186-189 for a thorough description of the site).Dated to the 1st-2nd c. AD from the diagnostic of the surface pottery by R. Tomber (the pottery was abundant).

name: Umm Khariga
short description: Mining settlement and possible stop on the Edfu-Marsa Nakari road during the Ptolemaic period
description: New Kingdom gold mining settlement, according to R. and D. Klemm, who saw tools on the surface that they date to the New Kingdom.The University of Delaware visited the site in 1997 (called Abu Greiya by Sidebotham 1999, p. 366) and describes the surface pottery as Ptolemaic. It is unclear whether this site is equivalent to the Klemms' New Kingdom site or if it is distinct from it, but it is likely one and the same. During that period, the site was settled near or by the ancient Edfu-Marsa Nakari (Nechesia?) road, and could have acted as a stopping point on the road.The mining settlement is composed of a cluster of huts. No mine is recorded in the vicinity.

name: Umm Maryah/Umm Ushra/Umm Qaria
short description: Ptolemaic station on the Edfu-Berenike road with later reoccupation
description: Site located in the wadi Maryah, also called Umm Qaria or Umm Ushra. According to Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 165, water is available in the vicinity, sometimes at only 20 m deep in the wadis.The site of Umm Maryah hosted a Ptolemaic station with two oval tanks. The D shape of the station is original, however the station is similar to many other Ptolemaic stations on the Edfu-Berenike road.The date of the station is probably Early Ptolemaic, as shown by the surface pottery found by the Michigan and Delaware surveys (with some very early finds, dated to the fourth to third c. BC). The station was probably contemporaneous with the setting and organization of the road system by Ptolemy II, on the Edfu-Berenike road.Later pottery was also recovered by the Michigan and Delaware surveys, dated to the Late Ptolemaic and Early Roman period, as well as to the fourth to fifth c. AD. Like the fort of Abbad for example, this probably means that the station was still visited either by shepherds or travelers.

name: Umm Mirayr
short description: Christian settlement off the road
description: Late Roman Christian settlement off the road. Noted by Sidebotham 2011 (Umm Mureer) as being between Sukkari and Wadi Umm Kharega, near the Marsa Nakari- Appollonopolis road, but not otherwise described. The coordinates given here mark the best candidate in the area that is visible on satellite imagery, although it is uncertain if this is the site Sidebotham visited.

name: Umm Naqqat
short description: Roman quarrying settlement
description: Quarrying settlement, comprising a large open-cut quarry of pegmatitic diorite, and an Early Roman settlement at the foot of the hill where the quarry stands.The settlement is composed of 8 buildings, of 1 to 4 rooms, that are well-built with angular corners.The objects sent from the quarry have not been identified, but the stone looks very similar to the ones extracted from the quarry of Umm Shegilat, hence a possibile confusion (Harrell in Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 64).A Late Predynastic cemetery is also recorded in the vicinity.According to Sidebotham 2011b, p. 120-121, the Delaware survey was able to follow a Roman route leading from the quarry to the Marsa Nakari-Edfu road.

name: Umm Rashid
short description: New Kingdom gold settlements
description: New Kingdom gold settlements along the wadi, over 1.8 km.

name: Umm Rus
short description: New Kingdom mining settlement
description: Miners' site located in a narrow valley, at the NNW of the Umm ar-Rus mines and overlooking the wadi al-Magal.Comprises a New Kingdom mining area, with a miner's village called "Umm Rus Magal" (huts) and "Umm Rus Mines" (mines).

name: Umm Salatit
short description: New Kingdom and Ptolemaic settlements and tailings
description: Near a modern road north of Gebel el-Hamri, clusters of houses are visible on satellite imagery. The survey by D. and R. Klemm revealed a New Kingdom and Ptolemaic occupation. Tools from the two periods and Ptolemaic pottery prove that there was gold exploitation in this area during these periods.

name: Umm Salim
short description: New Kingdom settlement
description: Both sides of Wadi Umm Salim, several huts were built during the New Kingdom. They are linked to a quartz tailing that reveals a gold exploitation in the wadi.

name: Umm Samra
short description: New Kingdom settlements and mine
description: New Kingdom settlements and mine.

name: Umm Shegilat
short description: Roman quarrying settlement
description: Quarrying settlement, comprising a quarry of pegmatitic diorite, north of Mons Claudianus, 16km from the Roman station of Qattar and 17km from the Ptolemaic miner village and Roman station of Ghozza. A small settlement is located on the slopes of the hill where the quarry is. It comprises half a dozen isolated buildings and an agregation of 15 rooms organised in a sub-square building of ca 16 x 18m.According to Cuvigny 2018a, p. 34, the quarry may have been in the orbit of the Porphyrites, and accessed from Qena via Ghozza.According to the Gazetteer of Stone Quarries in the Roman world, the stone extracted is "Large-grained black and white granite (granito della colonna); exported to Rome in the Roman Imperial period in small quantities" (Russel 2013, p. 58). See also Cuvigny 2018a, note 59 on the use of the stone.The quarry was already in exploitation in the Late Predynastic to Early Dynastic period, and in the Roman period, more precisely during the 1st/2nd c. AD (Brown, Harrell 1995, p. 224).According to the Egyptian engineer who found the quarry, a Roman well is located nearby (Gnoli 1971, p. 126, n.2). It is not visible on satellite images and is not recorded on the topographical map. The reference may refer to the Bir Umm Disi that is located ca 6km to the NW.

name: Umm Sidrah
short description: Ruined building at the junction of the wadi el-Maamal and the wadi Umm Sidrah, probably animal lines
description: Ruined building at the junction of the wadi el-Maamal and the wadi Umm Sidrah.According to Scaife, it could be the animal lines for the whole site of the Porphyrites (Meredith 1952, p. 100). It is indeed located near a juncture point between a big loading ramp, coming from the quarries, and the wadi Umm Sidrah, where the main settlement of the area stands, with the Roman fort.The structures are similar to the Badia animal lines, and other examples found in the Eastern Desert. To the west, a tank was probably used to supply the troughs.The remains are poorly dated, but could be contemporaneous with the animal lines of Badia, i.e. the Antonine period (Maxfield, Peacock 1998, p. 192).For a thorough description, and comparison with other animal lines, see Maxfield, Peacock 2011b, p. 202-209.

name: Umm Suwagi
short description: Stop on the Via Hadriana
description: Cistern and other structures. Stop on the Via Hadriana according to the Delaware University survey. The site has been destroyed by floods and modern works nearby (Beni Mazar-Gharib highway) and is not visible on the satellite images, as shown by the Florence survey results.From the plan published in Sidebotham, Zitterkopf 1998, fig. 2, one can see that the site comprises a small circular well, protected by some walls. A large and circular area with scattered stones maybe indicate the presence of other remains. To the north there is also a rectangular cistern of ca 10 x 6m.Sidebotham 2011b pg. 129 suggests the possibility of Late Roman activity here.

name: Umm Towat
short description: Quarries of blue-grey (trachayandesite) porphyry in activity in the first to second century AD
description: Quarries of blue-grey (trachayandesite) porphyry in activity in the first to second century AD.Located ca 6 km from Umm Balad, with no natural way between the two sites. A well-made Roman road has been followed for about 4 km, and leads to the main Roman road to the Porphyrites.No settlement is recorded and only three extraction points are indicated in Bagnall, Harrell 2003, p. 231-235, on both sides of the wadi. Near a 12m long quarry front is a small stone hut.A few hundred meters to the south of the quarry are two buildings, 3.5 and 5.5 square.The surface pottery is scarce and dates to the Early Roman period.There are few objects made in the Umm Towat stone in Rome (see Cuvigny 2018a, p. 34). According to Bagnall, Harrell 2003, p. 231-234, the stone extracted in Umm Towat could be called "knekites" in an inscription found in the Porphyrites.

name: Umm Wikalah
short description: Roman quarrying settlement and fort, known as "Ophiates" in Antiquity
description: The Umm Wikalah quarries are located on both sides of the Wadi Umm Wikalah. Green metagabbro was exploited here (see J. Harrell's chapter in Sidebotham et al. 2001, p. 142 on the type of stone). The Wikalah quarries are the "next largest Roman quarry in the Eastern desert after those of Mons Claudianus and Mons Prophyrites" (Sidebotham et al. 2001, p. 135).The whole quarrying district is called Mons Ophiates in an inscription found in situ, which probably points to the nature of the stone (ophites in Greek refers to the snake, the stone had the appearance of snake markings).Apart from quarry fronts, slipways, platforms, crudely-made shelters and cairns (all typical of quarry contexts), several skopeloi (watch-towers), an organised settlement, as well as two chapels dedicated to the god Pan/Min in the Early Roman period, and small cemeteries are located in the district. For a thorough description of the quarry, see Sidebotham et al. 2001. Despite the quality of the data, not all of the features recorded by the survey could be located on the satellite images (44 features in total, of which 13 quarry excavations and 7 platforms where the semi-finished stone products were probably moved after they were excavated, until they were carried to the Nile valley on chariots).The site is located ca 2.1km to the N of the Roman fort of Deir el-Wikalah, which gave access to and controlled the quarries.

name: Wadi el-Bayzah settlements
short description: Pharaonic settlements, probably New Kingdom gold settlements
description: Three clusters of huts are located on the edges of the Wadi el-Bayzah. Thanks to their architecture and the tools found by the Egyptian Eastern Desert Expedition (Rothe, Miller, Rapp 2008), we know they date from the Pharaonic Period, probably the New Kingdom, and that they are related to the exploitation of gold mines in the area.

name: Zeidun
short description: Sanded up well and possible gold mine; Bedouin tombs
description: Ancient mining site according to Hume 1937, p. 733, but the Klemms were unable to see anything in the field (they report circular Bedouin tombs, looted, which Hume may have mistaken for worker's huts). Nothing is visible on BingMap and the GPS point given by the Klemms is in the wadi, near the tombs and well, but the mine, if it exists, is probably in the mountains.The site of the well was visited by the Delaware survey, which noticed a mortarium and some non-diagnostic sherds. These were likely Roman, but this is unconfirmed according to Sidebotham, Gates-Foster 2019, p. 269. A large cairn built of sandstone cobbles is nearby. Winkler recorded the presence of hieroglyphic, Kufic Arabic, and "Roman Greek" inscriptions, some of these latter being dated to the reign of Tiberius, located somewhere "north of the wadi Zeidun" at a Roman rock shrine dedicated to Pan, but they are imprecisely located and not necessarily very near the well and settlement, although it seems a good candidate. Subsequent missions did not see them.
